webTitle: Irish luck fails to hold out in Amsterdam

fields.headline: Irish luck fails to hold out
fields.standfirst:
Holland 2 (Robbie Keane, McAteer)
Republic of Ireland 2 (Talan, Van Bronckhorst)
fields.trailText: Irish come close to famous triumph in Amsterdam
fields.byline: Nicholas Harling at the Amsterdam Arena
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland's eventful week came within a whisker of ending with a glorious triumph here in the Amsterdam Arena.

The coach, Mick McCarthy, who banned Phil Babb and Mark Kennedy from playing in this match, must have felt his decision was fully vindicated when goals from Robbie Keane and Jason McAteer promised a staggering outcome. But it was not quite to be. Holland fought back, avoiding an embarrassing home defeat with goals by Jeffrey Talan and Giovanni van Bronckhorst, two of the most unlikely marksmen.

A torrential downpour in the afternoon had long since given way to a near-balmy evening by the time the game kicked off, with the Republic of Ireland playing towards the goal behind which sat 7,000 of their supporters.

Within eight minutes, Robbie Keane was displaying a hint of things to come with a spirited 50-yard dash that began when he left Frank de Boer for dead on the halfway line. Richard Dunne, Mark Kinsella and Roy Keane were all involved in the subsequent exchange of passes before Kevin Kilbane's deep left-wing cross was met by Niall Quinn beyond the far post. His header thudded against the outside of the near-upright to the relief of the majority of the crowd, most of whom were clad in orange replica shirts.

Ireland threatened again when Stephen Carr was brought down by Giovanni van Bronckhorst on the edge of the area, but Ian Harte's free-kick carried no great danger for the Dutch.

Holland suddenly got their act into order after Frank de Boer had found Michael Reiziger with a pinpoint cross-field pass. The full-back, who faces a Fifa sanction after his pre-match declaration on his website that Holland would try to get Roy Keane sent off, cut inside to fire just wide. As for Roy Keane, he was his usual indefatigable self, cajoling, running, tackling, and doing little to generate animosity among his opponents.

Ireland were clearly in the middle of an uncomfortable period, however. There was an anxious moment for Harte when Ronald de Boer tumbled into the area after his challenge. The Slovakian referee waved aside Dutch appeals for a penalty. Ireland's torrid time continued but Richard Dunne managed to get his brow in the way of a goal-bound header from Frank de Boer after a corner from his twin brother. Dunne and Gary Breen were, thankfully, looking sharp in the Irish defence despite having mustered only 80 minutes of Premiership football between them this season.

Yet it was another member of the over-worked Irish defence who started the move that led to Robbie Keane's seventh international goal. Carr extricated himself from an unpromising situation near the right corner flag to supply Jason McAteer, who promptly whipped over a cross that was met by Inter's new £12 million signing with a decisive header that gave Edwin van der Sar no chance in the Dutch goal.

Renewed confidence surged through the Irish ranks and Harte almost made it two moments later when he sped on to Kilbane's long raking pass only to fail narrowly with a cross-shot. That was more excusable than Quinn's next miss. He could only respond with a weak shot after a slip by Bert Konterman, reminiscent of his wretched contribution the previous weekend for Rangers against Celtic.

Holland, now under the control of Louis van Gaal, were still exhibiting the same lack of penetration that proved so costly to his predecessor, Frank Rijkaard, during Euro 2000. Not until the 41st minute, when Dunne blocked a low shot from Paul Bosvelt, did they seriously threaten again. Soon afterwards Patrick Kluivert, having recovered from being dumped on his backside by Dunne near the corner flag, got too much under a cross from Ronald de Boer. Ireland once again cleared the danger but the pressure was back on at the start of the second half.

Holland resumed with Clarence Seedorf, on for Barcelona's Reiziger, giving them extra vision and pace in midfield. By the time Van Gaal made another change on the hour, bringing on Arnold Bruggink for his first cap for Richard Witschge, who had made little impression in mid-field, Ireland had gone close again. Quinn flung himself at another cross from Kilbane but was sadly once more off target. Not so McAteer, when the Blackburn player rifled in the second Irish goal from 30 yards with his weaker left foot after a move involving Quinn and Robbie Keane. The Dutch were now seriously up against it, much to the joy of the ecstatic Irish following.

Hearts were soon in Irish mouths, however. Talan had been on the field only six minutes as the third Dutch substitute when, with a stooping header, he scored the goal that gave Van Gaal's team a glimmer of hope. The move started when the ball ran kindly for Kluivert out on the left. The Barcelona striker, scorer of the two goals that had ended Ireland's hopes of Euro 96 qualification the last time the nations met, found Ronald de Boer, whose cross picked out Talan at the far post. The midfielder who will shortly be appearing in the Champions League for Heerenveen just beat Harte to the centre. Gary Kelly was beaten again in the 84th minute when Van Bronckhorst swerved a vicious drive into the roof of the net from fully 35 yards.

Holland Van der Sar, Reiziger (Seedorf 46), Konterman (Talan 65), F. de Boer, Van Bronckhorst, Bosvelt, R. de Boer, Witschge (Bruggink 60), Kluivert, Cocu, Bouma. Subs not used: Ricksen, Lurling, Vennegoor, Westerveld.

Rep of Ireland A. Kelly, Carr, Harte, Dunne, Breen, R. Keane, McAteer (G. Kelly 74), Kinsella, N. Quinn (Connolly 71), R. Keane, Kilbane (Staunton 79). Subs not used: Duff, Kiely, Finnan, Foley.

Referee L. Michel (Slovakia).

fields.headline: Yorkshire fury over inspector 'conspiracy'
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 356 & 89-3dec
Yorkshire 158 & 68-0
Match drawn
fields.trailText:
Surrey 356 & 89-3dec
Yorkshire 158 & 68-0
Match drawn.
fields.body:
The formalities of a token final session were half done, Yorkshire batting out a draw which will bring them little benefit, when the public address gave the Test score: England had lost two early wickets, one of them Hussain for another duck. That brought an approving cheer. The England captain may be an Essex man, but with Yorkshire folk in their present mood, all southerners are tarred with the same brush.

The animosity generated here could last long. Alternatively it may be a catalyst for change. Home opinion has been scathing about the eight-point penalty for a pitch that was judged to be too grassy, allowing too much sideways movement. And yesterday Bob Platt, the county's cricket chairman, was on the warpath as he complained about the circumstances in which a pitch inspector appeared last Wednesday.

He alleges that the Surrey players knew that an inspector would be coming. 'Why should that make any difference?' was the reaction to that by an English Cricket Board spokesman. 'No one should mind an inspector coming, if the pitch is OK.'

More inspectors have been employed this season - not waiting, as previously, to be called in - and the ECB estimate that one has been present at the start of around half the games.

All administrators presumably accept the need for penalties for poor pitches, but with feelings running so high changes must be made. The idea of all groundsmen being employed directly by the ECB has been regularly debated, only to be resisted for logistic reasons. The other, more radical, idea will now gain support: the scrapping of the traditional toss for innings, with the visiting side being given the choice of bowling or batting on the surface prepared by the home club.

The second time around, young Simon Widdup and Vic Craven batted with much more composure in the 25 overs before both sides called it a day. The draw - and the deduction of points - puts Yorkshire out of the chase and leaves Lancashire, 19 points behind, the only possible challengers to Surrey's title.

webTitle: Betting the house on a cheaper loan

fields.headline: Betting the house on a cheaper loan
fields.standfirst: Borrowers need plans to repay interest-only mortgages, says  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Borrowers need plans to repay interest-only mortgages, says Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Thousands of homebuyers with cheap interest-only mortgages do not know how they will pay off their loans when the terms end. One client of mortgage broker John Charcol planned to sell his vintage car to settle up.

But lenders, most of whom do not compel clients to set up arrangements to repay these loans, are beginning to acknowledge that these vulnerable borrowers have a problem.

They choose these loans because the monthly repayments can be significantly lower than for a traditional capital and interest or repayment loan, or one backed by an endowment policy, an individual savings account or a pension. Monthly payments for a £100,000 repayment mortgage at 7.5 per cent over 25 years will be around £750. The monthly outlay on an interest-only loan would be nearly £125 cheaper, at £625.

Ray Boulger of John Charcol says they can work well for highly paid people, typically City workers who receive large bonuses that pay off chunks of capital. They can also work well for young people, who expect their earnings to rise rapidly.

'You can take out the loan on a 25-year term, pay interest-only for two or three years and then put a repayment mortgage in place.'

He agrees, however, that interest-only is right only for those with a clear strategy for repaying the debt.

Mortgage broker Clive Miers says most of his clients are concerned about ensuring that they have a method of repayment in place. However, he is receiving an 'enormous' number of calls from people who have cancelled endowment policies because of fears that the insurance policies linked to their loans may not be enough to repay the debt.

Normally, cancellation is not advisable because of poor early-surrender values. Miers says those with the better-paying life insurers, such as Standard Life or Scottish Widows, may receive encashment values that contribute usefully to repaying the loan.

Those cutting their losses from endowments are putting the remainder of the mortgage on a repayment system, often choosing a flexible loan that allows lump-sum repayments. Whatever happens, Miers adds, borrowers cancelling policies should find other ways to repay the capital.

Another category of borrower who may be at risk with interest-only loans are those who took out personal equity plans instead of endowments. Peps were abolished more than a year ago and there are fears that many homeowners have put nothing in their place.

Lenders are already required by the Mortgage Code to put a warning notice on annual statements about repayment, but the industry was criticised by Which? magazine recently for failing to do enough to find out whether borrowers were making adequate repayment arrangements. The magazine questioned the 20 top lenders, and only Halifax, HSBC and the Royal Bank of Scotland were checking on clients' repayment methods before releasing loans.

The four lenders that made 'the least effort' to prevent borrowers being left with no means of repaying their loans were Alliance & Leicester, Bradford & Bingley building society; Cheltenham & Gloucester and Woolwich.

Which? pointed out that the Banking Ombudsman regularly receives complaints from people who belatedly discover that no endowment has been set up for their loans, even though they believed this had happened. Often this is due to administrative bungling.

Lenders are beginning to act. Some fear they will be blamed if a large number of elderly borrowers lose their homes in future because no one checked up on their plans for repayment.

Portman building society started a rolling programme of mailings to borrowers earlier this year asking whether they had repayment vehicles in place. The society says the initial response was disappointing, although replies have trickled in since.

Around 60 per cent of Portman's loans are interest-only.

Spokesman John Gully believes most of these bor rowers have some method of repayment in place. But it could be an endowment that will fall short, or an inadequate Isa savings account.

He warns: 'I have a feeling that people settle down with a mortgage, tuck a bit of money away but are not building up a fund big enough to repay the loan at the end of the term.'

fields.headline: Political? Be proud of it
fields.standfirst: Far from being an aberration, politics is essential to running a company.  Simon Caulkin  on the art of the possible
fields.trailText: Far from being an aberration, politics is essential to running a company. Simon Caulkin on the art of the possible.
fields.body:
The idea that business and politics don't mix is one of management's most deeply ingrained myths. When people say of a corporation, for instance, or an NHS hospital that 'it's a very political organisation', it's not meant as a compliment.

In the same way, 'he or she plays politics', is a damning assessment of a person. But the ideal of a company as a politics-free zone is getting harder and harder to sustain. It was born of an era where rationality and control were the paramount values, and hierarchy and bureaucracy the logical management expression of them. Unfortunately the world is no longer predictable and stable, but chaotic and volatile.

The attempt to impose top-down solutions is more a help than a hindrance, so the simplistic vision of management as an exercise in machine-like rationality doesn't wash any more.

Dr David Butcher, who leads executive seminars on organisational politics at Cranfield Management School, points out that as long as 50 years ago the theorist Herbert Simon described the behaviour of people in organisations as resembling 'temporary coalitions of interested parties who occasionally do things together'.

That view was heretical then, and it is still at odds with much of the conventional theoretical account of the firm.

Yet the Simonian notion of organisations as inherently political, says Butcher, strikes chords with managers at every level: junior executives who witness the yawning gap between espoused values such as empowerment and the unspoken command-and-control reality; middle managers who are only too conscious of finding their best ideas squashed because of political considerations; and senior executives who, the moment they reach the top, cannot avoid realising that every decision they make, whether on management appointments, the siting of a new plant or investing in a new internet venture, is political before all else.

In fact, says Butcher, once it's accepted that business management is no longer a matter of identifying the one right solution, the parallels between 'politics' with a big 'P' and the organisational variety are greater than commonly supposed - or than the normal language of management allows.

Both are fundamentally about resolving the clash of competing causes. In reaching this resolution, drafting white papers, canvassing interested parties, lobbying, leaks and deals in smoke-filled rooms are all part of the political game.

But while in democratic politics everyone accepts that when a matter finally reaches Parliament it is really all over bar the shouting (sometimes literally), there is no comparable language, ritual or institution to legitimise the process in companies. The result: years of wasted management effort, frustration and eventually cynicism as decision-making obstinately refuses to obey the rational logic that managers try to impose on it.

Treating organisations as political in this sense has far-reaching implications. For a start, it makes management a fundamentally moral activity.

This, explains Butcher, is because any democratic political system can only function on the assumption that the competing causes are founded on good faith, not ill will or wickedness. The debate is genuine. It follows that the only difference between 'good' and 'bad' politics is the motivation of the people involved. Most ends are justified if the cause is good. 'Good' politics is about competing to bring the greatest benefits to others; including stakeholders, by definition. 'Bad' politics is what diverts people's energies into negative or self-serving ends.

The big step, says Butcher, is to get people to accept that, far from being an aberration, politics is a legitimate and necessary activity in companies - an inevitable part of the daily work of getting things done. Some people never make that step: the shock to the conventional mindset is too great to accept. But only at that point is it possible to start to build the basic political understanding and fluency with which companies can resolve the tension between the warring 'rational' and 'irrational' sides of their decision-making.

Once people have made the mindset switch, says Butcher, they are unlikely to switch back again to the old attitudes - although back in the real world of their companies they may have to pretend. Indeed, continuing to deliver according to the old rules of the game, while promoting a different agenda, is one of the key political competences. Others are self-knowledge, being extremely careful about where you put your trust and developing informal ways of managing upward - it's pointless, not to mention career-limiting, to stride into open battle for a good cause against an immediate boss whom you know to be hostile if you can find your way around him or her.

Political skills are particularly important for managers in organisations that are in the throes of large-scale change. Since it puts group and individual interests at stake, change is fertile ground for all the elements of political agitation - genuine debate about the company's future options mingles with rumours, hidden agendas and jockeying for position in a vortex of speculation and coalition building.

Of course, failure to recognise the political dimension may be one reason why companies find change notoriously hard to manage to a proper conclusion. That at least was the tentative finding of consultancy AT Kearney which, echoing the results of other studies of the same subject, in a recent survey of 300 European companies found that only 17 per cent were achieving change of the extent, timeliness and durability that they planned.

Managers, suggests Kearney, persistently overestimate the importance of the rational, economic components of change and correspondingly underestimate the political and social. Organisations are made up of human beings, and all dimensions of their behaviour must be engaged to push change through. It's a lesson we should have learnt by now. What is politics, after all, but the art of the possible?

Of course, failure to recognise the political dimension may be one reason why companies find change notoriously hard to manage to a proper conclusion. That at least was the tentative finding of consultancy AT Kearney which, echoing the results of other studies of the same subject, in a recent survey of 300 European companies found that only 17 per cent were achieving change of the extent, timeliness and durability that they planned. Managers, suggests Kearney, persistently overestimate the importance of the rational, economic components of change and correspondingly underestimate the political and social. Organisations are made up of human beings, and all dimensions of their behaviour must be engaged to push change through. It's a lesson we should have learnt by now. What is politics, after all, but the art of the possible?

fields.headline: Seductive rates can be deceiving
fields.standfirst: Take a close look at the new savings products, advises  Sylvia Morris
fields.trailText: Take a close look at the new savings products, advises Sylvia Morris.
fields.body:
Amid fierce competition, savings account providers are continuing to launch a flurry of new products paying attractive rates of interest.

Banks and building societies are continually launching new accounts available through the high street, over the telephone, through the post or on the Internet.

However, before being seduced by the high rates of interest currently on offer, savers need to ask three questions:

Is there a bonus payable and for how long does it last? Is there an underlying guarantee on the account? And, are there withdrawal restrictions?

The first of these questions is particularly pertinent. New accounts often include a bonus - sometimes as much as 1.25 percentage points on top of the normal rate -which boosts the headline interest rate. These bonuses only last for a set period, after which the account may become much less competitive.

Birmingham Midshires' new SimplySave, for example, a telephone-based account paying 6.85 per cent a year before tax (worth 5.45 per cent after 20 per cent savings tax), offers an exceptionally good rate.

But the headline includes a 0.75 percentage point bonus which expires on 2 January next year. The account comes with a guarantee that it will pay no less than 0.5 percentage points below Bank of England base rates until 2 January 2001. On this basis, and assuming current base rates, savers might be getting as little as 5.5 per cent a year (4.4 per cent) from January.

Similarly, Abbey National's Direct Saver, a phone or cashpoint card-based account, pays 6.55 per cent a year (5.24 per cent) including a 1 percentage point bonus on a minimum investment of £2,000. This is a very good rate but the bonus is due to disappear on 31 August. Thereafter, the rate, 5.55 per cent (4.44 per cent), is uncompetitive - it lags behind First Active's offering of 6.52 per cent (5.41 per cent) a year. And the rate could well slip further.

Bristol & West's Call One telephone account used to pay 7.05 per cent (5.6 per cent) a year on a minimum investment of £5,000. But now that the bonus rate period has expired, savers are getting 6.05 per cent (4.84 per cent) a year. This account comes with a guarantee that savers will not earn less than 0.75 percentage points below base rates before December next year. But while this is a comfort, the reality is that it can cut its rate to 5.25 per cent (4.2 per cent) a year.

Top-paying accounts offering good long-term rates and easy access to your money include offerings from First Active and Legal & General.

First Active Rate Tracker, with a minimum investment of £1,000, resets its rates on the fifth of each month to the rate equal to the average rate paid by the top 20 easy access accounts, including bonuses, on £10,000.

Legal &General's Easy Access Tracker links its rate to the three-month London Interbank Offered Rate (Libor) - the rate at which banks lend to each other - at the end of February, May, August and November.

Once the rate is set, it holds until the next review. L&G guarantees to pay a rate equal to Libor until February next, when it drops to Libor less 0.5 per cent.

Meanwhile, banks and building societies have been cutting the rates they pay on new issues of their fixed rate bonds. Three months ago, when Money Observer warned that such bonds were at their peak, savers could fix at 7.25 to 7.5 per cent before tax a year (5.8 to 6 per cent after 20 per cent savings tax or 4.35 to 4.5 per cent after 40 per cent tax) for two to three years.

The best deals now stand at 6.75 to 7 per cent a year (5.4 to 5.6 per cent for basic rate payers or 4.05 to 4.2 per cent for higher rate payers).

Higher-rate taxpayers will do better with National Savings' Two-Year Fixed Rate Savings Certificates, Issue 4, which pay a fixed, tax-exempt 4.5 per cent a year on £100 plus.

webTitle: How to work where you are the only man

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: ...work where you are the only man
fields.trailText: ...work where you are the only man
fields.body:
1 Don't expect it to be a healthy work environment. When the sexes are segregated, they can become caricatures. In the absence of men, some women will become obsessed with talking about sex. In places where women dislike being in a female ghetto, there can be bullying and cruelty - convents, for instance, especially where the novices were forced to enrol at a young age.

2 Understand the reasons why women choose certain work - nannying, for instance, teaching, nursing, librarianship, PR and part-time jobs. Some may be attracted to the 'caring' professions; many will enjoy the field of communications; and large numbers will appreciate the family-friendly policies that flourish in many of these industries. But there can be a price to pay if naturally ambitious women are forsaking a more fulfilling career.

3 Recognise the benefits. Women colleagues are more likely to admit they are wrong, to apologise and to be content to be out of the limelight. Novelist Wendy Holden, author of Bad Heir Day , used to work on women's magazines: 'One of the strengths of women is their attitude to detail. They could pick up a phrase someone used in an interview and build another feature on that.' Men are more likely, Holden feels, to want the glamour of suggesting a big original idea.

4 Be wary of the stereotypes of 'women bosses' and the alleged bitchiness of female workplaces. If this happens, it probably relates to other causes such as the fact that fewer women reach the boardroom and there's a greater insecurity perhaps among those who want to get there. The gossip that surrounds them will almost always accentuate the fact that they are female - suggesting that they are sleeping their way to the top, for instance.

5 Take advantage of the far franker emotional environment. Few women will think the worse of Sandra for crying at her desk after getting bad news - an action which would horrify colleagues in a male office. As John Gray outlines in Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus , most women relish the giving and taking of sympathy and advice. In concentrated form, however, it can become too much. Maureen was eventually ground down by the caring environment of her all-female team: 'If someone had a headache, at least three people would remember and ask about it the next day.'

webTitle: Microsoft in $500m bid to beat Sony at its own game

fields.headline: Microsoft in $500m bid to beat Sony at its own game
fields.trailText: Microsoft will spend a staggering half a billion dollars marketing its new Xbox games console.
fields.body:
Microsoft will spend a staggering half a billion dollars marketing its new Xbox games console.

Ed Fries, Microsoft's vice president of games publishing who will outline the software giant's vision of an interactive world later today at the European Computer Trade Show in London, told The Observer: 'We have very aggressive forecasts and we'll be spending more than half a billion dollars in the first 18 months to promote the product worldwide. We're going to put a huge push behind Xbox.'

Fries hinted that Microsoft was preparing to take a massive hit on the Xbox to steal market share from Sony, maker of Playstation II. 'We understand that price is crucial to any consumer market. Traditionally, the way a console business works is that you sell the hardware for less than it costs you to produce it and charge a royalty on the software. We believe we'll be very competitive on price.'

Later today Microsoft will announce that it has signed up 18 software development studios to write exclusive content for the Xbox, which will be launched late next year. Included in the line-up is the UK's Lionhead Studios, founded by Peter Molyneux, who made millions when he sold his original company, Bullfrog, to the world's largest games publisher, Electronic Arts.

Some console manufacturers have suffered from a shortage of good games. However, Molyneux said today's announcement meant Microsoft's commitment to the video game market was serious. 'It's a very important step forward. Without world class video game talent you're going to flounder.'

fields.headline: Anyway, anyhow, anywhere
fields.standfirst: Office life is doomed. Soon we'll be operating from the remotest of places
fields.trailText: Office life is doomed. Soon we'll be operating from the remotest of places.
fields.body:
'When I arrived in Johannesburg, I jumped into a hire car and drove up to a game reserve. As I hadn't had time to send the document back to London until I got to the reserve, I parked next to an elephant quietly eating a small tree, and emailed London.'

No jokes about trunk calls please, this is Christopher Davis's career he's talking about. And while this sort of surfing safari is not an everyday activity, it's not atypical either. Davis is a virtual solicitor, one of a growing band of teleworkers working from home or other locations far away from their office base. He maintains contact with clients and colleagues worldwide though email, mobile phone and the internet.

This year the number of teleworkers like Davis will hit 10 million in Europe and by 2005 the figure will comfortably exceed 16 million - more than 10 per cent of the European workforce. Finland leads the way but, with a quarter of a million new teleworkers since last spring, Britain is catching up fast. These statistics form part of a European-wide survey into teleworking to be published in London later this month at Telework 2000.

This is the first time the European teleworking conference has been held in the UK. Peter Johnston, head of the European Commission's information society directorate, who ordered the research, will be among the speakers. He says the EC sees the promotion of teleworking as central to achieving its aim of raising the proportion of Europeans of working age in employment from 61 per cent today to 70 per cent by 2010. 'We have to hit this target if we are to fund social security and pensions in the future and teleworking removes a lot of the barriers to working - particularly for women, older people and disabled people,' he says.

The EU is funding research into electronic methods of working to the tune of 50 million euros (£31 million). 'The European Social and Regional Development funds which exist to accelerate development in less-favoured regions of the EU have also been very effective in getting teleworking schemes onstream,' says Johnston. 'Teleworking is not just about greater efficiency and productivity, it is increasingly the most effective way to improve the work-life balance, the way to stimulate creativity and the way to achieve more efficient use of office space and transport infrastructures.'

Alan Denbigh, executive director of the TCA (the Telework and Telecentre Association) says: 'The conventional 9-5 workplace is actually unsuitable for work. The buildings are often unhealthy and there are constant interruptions.' He also believes that the traditional office environment with its fixed hours, clothing and hierarchies, all reminiscent of schooldays, is 'infantilising'. He says 'teleworkers are re-empowered and this increases productivity'.

'Any major organisation that has still not considered flexible working is going to miss out,' says Ursula Laws of the Institute of Employment Studies. Her organisation's figures show how far teleworking has spread. She says: 'There has been an increase of 22 per cent in employees teleworking and 15 per cent in self-employed, a 12 per cent increase in clerical working despite a general decrease in the clerical workforce and a growth in financial services, the strongest of all sectors, by 34 per cent.'

One type of business that could be revolutionised by teleworking is the call-centre, where demand for staff frequently exceeds supply. Only 4 per cent of call centre managers employ teleworkers, but 42 per cent expect to do so in the near future. Next time you break down your emergency call could well be taken by one of the 150 people working in the AA's virtual call centre. Denbigh says: 'It takes 18 months to build a call centre and a couple of weeks to set up a virtual one. Which would you choose? Teleworking reduces the overheads - there may be marginally increased technology costs but these are more than offset by savings in office space - and it increases flexibility as nobody wants to come into the office for just a couple of hours' work, but at home it's different.'

He says manufacturers of the technology such as BT and IBM are proving through their own working practices that the technology is up to the job. One former BT employer says: 'For years BT was advocating teleworking but not doing it itself. It has realised this and now lots of BT staff work from home.'

The teleworker's teleworker must be Volker Krieger. He lives in Germany and works for a Swiss technology corporate with customers all over Europe and Poland. 'I have at least three offices,' he says. 'Half of the time, it's my lap top which I frequently use in the car hooked up to a mobile phone, 20 per cent of the time I'm at home and 30 per cent of the time I work in one or other of our offices. About half of my work is virtual and half is physical - that is, face-to-face with the client, but that's expensive and time-consuming. I think I can reduce this to less than 20 per cent.'

Krieger believes teleworking will become the natural way of operating. 'It's a generational thing. Today's schoolchildren will be natural teleworkers. To them using the tools of teleworking is normal not new.'

Currently, transnational teleworking is limited but the European company statute will, when agreed by the EU countries, enable direct employer-employee relationships to be established across the national boundaries. Nevertheless, Denbigh suggests that there may be a geographical limit, at least as far as employees are concerned. 'The AA want all staff to live within 70 miles of the administration centre because of the need for meetings and supervisions.'

However, for freelancers even the sky is not the limit. Teleworkers in the UK and Ireland working with US companies simply adjust their own hours to the working day across the Atlantic.

Anna Brady works for a company with offices in California and New York from her flat in Dublin. 'Only one or two people in the entire company work on-site,' she says. 'The company runs newsgroups which give you an idea of the history of different projects, and of the personalities of other members of the virtual team. When I visited the US for the first time it was a surprise to see how some of these people looked in real life.'

Never having to look at the bloke at the next desk. Now that's a reason to telework.

Pros

1 Save time and money on travelling

2 More control over your work and other parts of your life

3 No interruptions, gossip or office politics

4 Improved quality of life

5 Greater opportunity for community involvement

6 Good for environment

Cons

1 Need high degree of personal motivation

2 Need space to work in

3 More dependent on technology

4 Potential lack of human contact

5 Could be frozen out in office politics

6 Can never escape from the office

7 Less distinction between work and home

webTitle: Safeway joins Tesco in magazines war

fields.headline: Safeway joins Tesco in magazines war
fields.trailText: Safeway is poised to wade into a vicious turf war in the magazine industry which is now close to prompting a full investigation by the Office of Fair Trading. The supermarket giant is to follow in the footsteps of rival Tesco, which recently stunned publishers by announcing that it will take delivery of magazines from only one national distributor.
fields.body:
Safeway is poised to wade into a vicious turf war in the magazine industry which is now close to prompting a full investigation by the Office of Fair Trading. The supermarket giant is to follow in the footsteps of rival Tesco, which recently stunned publishers by announcing that it will take delivery of magazines from only one national distributor.

Currently magazines are distributed via a regional franchise network, but Tesco has sounded the potential death knell of the system by signing up the wholesaler WH Smith News as the only distributor to its 658 stores. The Periodical Publishers' Association argues that once Tesco and other stores are stripped out of the franchises, rival wholesale distributors will find it uneconomic to deliver to the remaining smaller retailers.

A recent report suggested the net effect of Tesco's decision could ultimately be the closure of up to 12,000 newsagents and 15,000 jobs.

Many publishers are alarmed at the power the deal would grant Tesco. The supermarket chain has caused widespread outrage by threatening to delist a number of magazines produced by publisher Gruner & Jahr if the company doesn't sign up to its new deal.

Safeway's move comes as the PPA prepares to outline a series of proposals to overhaul the current national magazine distribution system in an attempt to persuade Tesco to back out of the new deal, due to start next month. A possible compromise solution would see magazine wholesalers use an auto mated system so that stocks are ordered electronically to reduce over-supply.

Tesco says this would allow stores to react to consumer demand more efficiently. webTitle: Help - how do credit card companies calculate their interest charges?

fields.headline: Help - how do credit card companies calculate their interest charges?
fields.trailText: Customers who pay their credit card bills in full by the statement demand date pay no interest at all, with a few exceptions.
fields.body:
Customers who pay their credit card bills in full by the statement demand date pay no interest at all, with a few exceptions. Those who do charge even when you clear the account include: Alliance & Leicester Diamond, Bank of Scotland 'One', Halifax Visa Balance, Lloyds TSB Asset Advance, Co-op Gold Advantage.

Otherwise, for the months that you do not pay your bill in full by the due date, you are charged interest on the whole balance and not just the amount left unpaid. In these circumstances, most cards start charging interest from the date you make the purchase. Until now, John Lewis has been generous and charged no interest until the first of the month after the payment due date. But from October, with sister store Waitrose, it will backdate interest to the date of purchase.

When you paid no interest until the due date, it made no difference whether you paid early or late in the month. But with interest clocking up from the day you shop, you can save interest by paying the bill when it arrives. Interest builds up daily, so the sooner you pay, the less interest you incur. If you pay the bill in full, you avoid interest anyway, so might as well pay at the last moment.

At the end of the month, card companies calculate your average daily balance. Assuming, in a 31-day month, you spent £2,000 on the 10th and £50 on the 20th: you have borrowed £2,000 for 22 days and £50 for 12 days. The daily average balance is £1,438.71. Multiply this by the monthly interest rate for the interest until the date of the statement. But this is only the start of the calculation. You then pay interest from the statement date until the time you pay the bill, again based on the daily average, but taking account of credits and money paid in. It means you are paying interest on the interest.

You can reduce interest charges by making large purchases late in the month. Your balance at the end of the month will be high but the daily average will be lower.

webTitle: Fletcher searches hard for a silver lining

fields.headline: Fletcher searches hard for a silver lining
fields.trailText: Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, was most reserved at the end of play, rather like the shy streaker who raced across the turf at 7.05pm, when almost everyone had gone home.
fields.body:
Duncan Fletcher, the England coach, was most reserved at the end of play, rather like the shy streaker who raced across the turf at 7.05pm, when almost everyone had gone home.

This was billed as the weekend in which England's cricket would come blinking into the sunlight after a decade in sullen hibernation, and when Fletcher would be anointed as the finest coach the side has ever had. And what did we get? Rain clouds and another England batting collapse.

Fletcher probably is the best coach England have had but yesterday the Zimbabwean farmer looked as if he had just suffered a disastrous crop failure.

First he saw his side subside from 221 for five to 281 all out. And then he saw Adrian Griffith mysteriously survive two very good lbw shouts.

"We would have liked a few more runs. A score of around 300 or 320 was what we had looked at. But, having said that, the wicket is assisting the bowlers.

"We would have liked a couple of wickets at the end. We bowled very well and the batsmen played and missed. It's seaming more than anything. It's gripping quite a lot.

"It's got drier and drier and become more difficult to play on. Our openers did really well but it's one of those surfaces where, if you lose a wicket, another one or two can go down quickly.

"Scoring is really difficult. But you can hang in there for long periods. It really depends on what happens in the first hour or two tomorrow morning. It will be an interesting period."

If England required any extra incentive they received it yesterday when it was announced that the team would share a bonus of £215,000 for winning the series. The money will come from the England and Wales Cricket Board and the sponsors Cornhill and Vodafone, and is in addition to the £160,000 they have already won for beating Zimbabwe and for winning the NatWest Series.

There is more rain forecast for today. But, even if England achieve a weather-assisted draw, West Indies can scarcely complain.

In Trinidad a decade ago Devon Malcolm bowled England to the brink of a famous victory that would have put them two up in the series with three to play.

But a heavy shower, some delaying tactics by the then West Indies captain Desmond Haynes and a broken hand suffered by Graham Gooch allowed the hosts to escape with a draw. They went on to level in Barbados before winning the series in Antigua.

But even if the sun shines today there is always the danger of a sharp shower from Brian Lara. If he produces one, Fletcher could not look more disappointed than last night.

fields.headline: Yorkshire gain from dry deluge
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 356 & 89-3
Yorkshire 158
fields.trailText:
Surrey 356 & 89-3
Yorkshire 158
fields.body:
Veterans must have been reminded of the good old days at North Marine Road yesterday, with Surrey and Yorkshire at each other's throats like so many tussles in the 50s. It was just a shame there was hardly any cricket.

Not that there was anything wrong with the weather, at least until thunderstorms swept in at tea-time. It had been a glorious morning and early afternoon, further evidence of the microclimate the locals are so proud of, which allowed virtually a full day on Thursday when it was raining all across the north.

Unfortunately that micro-climate also appears to include rain bubbling up from underneath the covers. For the umpires and players arrived in the morning to find the bowlers' run-up from the Pavilion End absolutely sodden. Rumours quickly spread around the ground, and even as far as the Oval, that the covers had been vandalised, but were categorically denied by the groundstaff, who spoke instead of the high water table.

The umpires, Barry Dudleston and John Harris, already less than popular with Yorkshire members who had woken up to the news that their team had been docked eight points for preparing a poor pitch, inspected four times between 11am and 3pm. It was embarrassing for the Yorkshire and Scarborough clubs, and infuriating for Surrey and the spectators - who booed, slow-handclapped, but mostly grumbled.

It did not take an expert in body language to deduce that one team wanted to play and the other did not. Yorkshire had far more to lose than gain from this match after being outplayed on the first two days, and suspicions about Surrey's role in the pitch punishment were hardly likely to make the home team's coach Martyn Moxon and captain David Byas inclined to compromise. The teams even had their lunch separately.

As Yorkshire were bowling, they won the argument until the umpires came up with a bizarre way to break the stalemate: play would start at 3.30, but could be called straight off again if any of the Yorkshire bowlers slipped in the mud.

After Chris Silverwood had delivered one uneventful over from the dry Trafalgar Square End, Matthew Hoggard resisted the temptation to make a point by taking a dive and instead bowled a maiden. But for Yorkshire, more help from the microclimate was on its way and, after Silverwood had Adam Hollioake caught in the deep and the players had trooped off for tea with only 11 overs bowled, the heavens opened, terminally.

Surrey may now be denied the win which would as good as seal them the title, although they will still resume today with a lead of 287, weather permitting, while a draw would be enough to preserve Yorkshire's hopes of finishing second ahead of Lancashire. They will not, however, be appealing against the eight-point penalty administered by the England and Wales Cricket Board's pitch inspectors, Mike Denness and Alan Fordham, although that does not mean they are happy about it.

"Our chairman will raise the whole operation of pitch liaison officers' inconsistency throughout the season with a view to representation to the ECB at the end of the season," said the Yorkshire committee's spokesman, Geoff Cope, who sat on the ECB panel which upheld Middlesex's appeal against a similar penalty following their match against Worcestershire at Southgate in July.

Yorkshire are therefore only the second county to be docked points under the ECB's liaison officer system, following Derbyshire in June - when Surrey were again the visitors, Dudleston an umpire, and Denness the PLO.

webTitle: Thomas hits out to remove the doubts

fields.headline: Thomas hits out to remove the doubts
fields.standfirst:
Essex 292 & 75-3
Glamorgan 507-9dec
fields.trailText:
Essex 292 & 75-3
Glamorgan 507-9dec
fields.body:
Ian Thomas enters the last three weeks of the season with a double mission: to help Glamorgan secure a place in the top tier of the championship and land himself a contract.

The 21-year-old left-hander would appear to have every chance of achieving his goals following a highly successful day's work that seems certain to cement the Welsh county's place among the top three to be promoted from the Second Division.

Thomas marked his championship debut with a composed 82 after Glamorgan had resumed on 360 for six. He occasionally drove with power and elegance but generally prospered by coaxing the ball into the gaps as Glamorgan totalled 507 for nine declared and earned a first-innings lead of 215.

Thomas is currently contracted on a match-to-match basis and due to complete a Sports Development course at the University of Wales Institute, in Cardiff, next May. "I hope I will be able to do enough to persuade the county to offer me a permanent contract," he said. "No one has yet approached me to discuss such a possibility but this performance might open the door to an offer."

Thomas, who has averaged around 50 for the second XI this summer, owed his elevation to the senior side to a spate of injuries which robbed them of Matthew Elliott, Adrian Shaw and Alex Wharf. But although he received a slice of luck when on 26, Ashley Cowan putting down a lofted drive after running round from long-on to long-off, he expressed disappointment at not going on to reach three figures.

Had he done so, he would have been the first Glamorgan player to achieve the feat on his first championship appearance since Matthew Maynard landed that distinction against Yorkshire in 1985.

Thomas was denied emulating his captain when he repeated the stroke which should have brought about his downfall earlier. On this occasion Will Jefferson was not to offer a reprieve as he held the catch just inside the long-off fence.

Glamorgan's total was only the second time they have reached 500 against Essex, the other instance being way back in 1948. Their cause was helped by some undistinguished bowling, Danny Law too often sending down deliveries that batsmen could afford to ignore, and Ricky Anderson looking well below his best after a three-month lay-off while recovering from a broken toe.

Glamorgan's formidable advantage left Essex facing a huge task even to salvage a draw. Even that, however, seems highly unlikely following a dismal final session, the start of which was delayed by rain.

Paul Grayson was caught behind by Maynard - appearing behind the stumps because of Shaw's groin injury - while pushing forward, Jefferson was undone by the guile of Robert Croft and Paul Prichard, having been put down at short leg early on, became Maynard's second victim when sweeping Dean Cosker.

Essex reached the close on 75 for three and in serious trouble. Glamorgan, meanwhile, were left scenting a victory which would greatly enhance their prospects of promotion. The two biggest obstacles to such an outcome appear to be Stuart Law and the weather - showers being forecast for today.

fields.headline: Blame game finds perfect partner
fields.standfirst: If yesterday's collapse doesn't suffice, a quick glance at its TV sponsors is enough to bring English cricket back down to earth
fields.trailText: Jim White finds a quick glance at its TV sponsors is enough to burst English cricket's bubble.
fields.body:
A survey of advertising agencies, published at the Edinburgh Television Festival, reveals that the least desirable programme to place commercials within is the cheery quiz show Wheel Of Fortune. Meanwhile they queue up to buy the commercial breaks between Ali G's magnificent comic ramblings.

There was, however, no mention in the report of the agencies' opinion of cricket - presumably because it doesn't even register. A couple of weeks ago, I had a go at the ads which appear in the breaks during Channel 4's coverage, a sad parade marshalled by the magnificently insincere Christopher Timothy.

Clearly, despite the sudden interest in the game following England's success, no one else wants to advertise in the slots as, a fortnight on, Mr Timothy is still there between overs, ordering his pub lunch and informing us he is growing wiser by the day.

In the week that the England and Wales Cricket Board is seeking new sponsors to replace Mr T's employers (Cornhill), the ad breaks must have made depressing viewing for its chief executive Tim Lamb and his colleagues. If loan sharks and companies offering funeral insurance to the over-60s are the only ones wishing to associate themselves with the game, it hardly represents a glowing commercial future.

Until, that is, Friday's grim morning session was alleviated by a ray of light. An ad was screened featuring a wide-boy presenter fresh from some Guy Ritchie movie, striding through a telephone call-centre while noisily informing us of the thousands available to anyone who has ever so much as stubbed a toe on a paving slab.

Step forward The Accident Group plc as the ideal new sponsors of English cricket. After all the calamities of the past few years, what could be more appropriate that than the company's slogan: "Where there's a blame, there's a claim."

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: Jason Gallian's crisp 82 from 98 balls put his Nottinghamshire side in command at the end of the third day of their Second Division match against Sussex at Trent Bridge.
fields.body:
Jason Gallian's crisp 82 from 98 balls put his Nottinghamshire side in command at the end of the third day of their Second Division match against Sussex at Trent Bridge.

The former England opener was the driving force behind two excellent partnerships, putting on 77 with Darren Bicknell and 70 with the veteran John Morris. In the process Gallian hit 13 fours and a mighty six off Robin Martin-Jenkins which disappeared into the adjacent car park.

The hosts finished a truncated day 241 ahead with seven second-innings wickets remaining. Earlier Sussex had been bowled out for 267, Andrew Harris finishing with six for 110 and Richard Montgomerie falling for 129.

Also in the Second Division, Warwickshire gave themselves a chance of beating the weather by building a first-innings lead of 104 over Worcestershire on another rain shortened day at Edgbaston. Only 20 overs were possible before lunch and a further 24 after 5pm, but Dominic Ostler moved past 50 for the seventh time in his benefit season.

The 30-year-old completed 1,000 runs for the summer as Warwickshire's overnight 224 for one turned into 367 for five. Mark Wagh added 12 to reach a championship best 130 before he was lbw to Glenn McGrath. Ostler made 88, including a partnership of 97 with Anurag Singh (42 not out), before he was run out by McGrath.

Heavy showers meant only three balls were bowled on the opening day of the First Division game at Taunton. Somerset still lost Mark Lathwell, who was caught behind off Leicestershire's Phil DeFreitas.

webTitle: Brilliant Brown spins through the rain

fields.headline: Brilliant Brown spins through the rain
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 186 &15-0
Northants 469
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 186 &15-0
Northants 469
fields.body:
Were Jason Brown a spinner of yarns rather than balls, he would make a top-notch confidence trickster. He is certainly doing his level best to fleece Gloucestershire, whom one trusts were busy last night sending emails to CelestialBody.com, pleading for a few more obliging bucketloads of the wet stuff.

Between the torrents that virtually halved yesterday's ration, Brown and Darren Cousins, the mainsprings of the home attack, claimed four scalps apiece, enabling Northamptonshire to enforce the follow-on. Brown now has 50 wickets at 19.38 in this term's championship, at the unheard-of strike rate - for a modern English off-spinner - of 48.88 balls per wicket.

Robert Croft's rate is twice that. Among the southpaws, Ashley Giles stands at 60.7, Phil Tufnell 68, Dipak Patel 74. Granted, Ian Salisbury strikes every 46 balls and Saqlain Mushtaq every 38, yet even Shane Warne only does so every 54.

His side's travails did not dissuade that broad-minded coach John Bracewell from expressing his admiration for the slight fellow who has done most to put the Second Division leaders in sight of a senior league title for the first time since they took the Second-Class (now Minor) Counties crown in 1904.

Indeed, he reckons Brown could be England's ace in the hole in next summer's Ashes' debate.

"Our batsmen tell me he gets lots of revs on the ball, really rips it," enthused Bracewell, showing due appreciation for the gifts of a fellow offie. "What I like is his line, the way he pitches the ball well outside off, aiming to hit off. That's the right line for Ashes cricket. If there's a weakness in the Australian side, any Australian side, it's against off-spin.

"They always want to work you to the on side, so they're closing the face of the bat early. And they don't like waiting for the ball. Steve Waugh recently decided to take the aerial route - the size of their grounds makes them reluctant to do that - but I think this bloke has the control to cope."

That said, Bracewell believes the selectors were justified in not selecting Brown for England's first tour of Pakistan since Mike Gatting clashed with Shakoor Rana. "I don't think you can get away with doing only one thing in Test cricket now," he said, referring to Brown's staunchly irresolute batsmanship. Three weeks ago, he confessed that he had not had a net all season.

Bracewell, who topped up his 104 wickets for New Zealand with 1,001 runs at 20, including a century against England, offers one worthwhile suggestion.

"Maybe," he proposes, "he should work at being a terrific fielder."

A quick chat with Roger Harper before the West Indies head off home might not be a bad idea.

He is certainly doing his level best to fleece Gloucestershire, whom one trusts were busy last night sending emails to CelestialBody.com, pleading for a few more obliging bucketloads of the wet stuff. Between the torrents that virtually halved yesterday's ration, Brown and Darren Cousins, the mainsprings of the home attack, claimed four scalps apiece, enabling Northamptonshire to enforce the follow-on. Brown now has 50 wickets at 19.38 in this term's championship, at the unheard-of strike rate - for a modern English off-spinner - of 48.88 balls per wicket. Robert Croft's rate is twice that. Among the southpaws, Ashley Giles stands at 60.7, Phil Tufnell 68, Dipak Patel 74. Granted, Ian Salisbury strikes every 46 balls and Saqlain Mushtaq every 38, yet even Shane Warne only does so every 54. webTitle: Dudgeon is the worse part of valour

fields.headline: Dudgeon is the worse part of valour
fields.standfirst: For all Robert Croft's protestations, his omission from the England party to tour Pakistan is probably just a little too close to home
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey on how Robert Croft's outburst after being left out of England's tour to Pakistan.
fields.body:
Personally this has been a disappointing week. On Monday the party to tour Pakistan was announced and yet again I had not been included. There was no sympathetic phone call from David Graveney, either, and no friendly message from Nasser saying bad luck but stick at it. That, frankly, is just poor man management and, as a consequence, I am announcing my retirement from international cricket with immediate effect. So there.

I could not help but notice that Robert Croft, too, had failed to impress the powers that be sufficiently to warrant selection. And, if anyone else had not spotted this, then they would have been left in no doubt by the sour outpourings that came from the off-spinner.

Nothing had changed in the England set-up, he grumbled; if only he had been given the same opportunities as Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Alec Stewart; the selectors pay too much attention to what is written in the papers; Glamorgan players have trouble attracting attention; and anyway if they had picked him he would have turned them down in any case so fed up was he, blah, blah, blah.

His knees must be buckling so heavy is the chip on his shoulder. "Sour grapes, do you think?" an interviewer on BBC Radio Wales asked me with the most massive understatement. Well, just a tad perhaps.

Actually in a way I feel rather sorry for a fellow who cares very much about playing for England, has never given less than his utmost effort when so doing, is genuinely disappointed and at a vulnerable moment has engaged gob before brain.

Nevertheless he has come out with such a litany of whingeing that it is hard to avoid the conclusion that these thoughts have been festering for some time and he was just waiting for the opportunity to air them.

Clearly he is a sadly deluded bloke who can rationalise his failure to establish himself as a fixture in the England side as a function of everything but his own fallibility as a player. In simple terms, he is not good enough - no disgrace in that provided you have given your all - but he cannot admit it.

The watershed came at Old Trafford when, having got back into the side at the start of the series, he was presented with a turning pitch, a collection of left-handers and told to go out and win the game. But 47 huffing, puffing, oohing, aahing, grimacing overs later he had taken just a single wicket for 124 and blown it. If a seamer had produced those figures on a greentop he would have been derided.

So what is his problem now? Is it the notion that his record abroad is massively superior to that at home (26 wickets at 23.27 - more than respectable - compared with 13 at 73.23)? Well, his inability to take wickets under pressure to do so counts against him just as it should with seamers, and of batsmen to make runs.

Is he just kidding himself when he suggests that the England management set-up under Hussain and Duncan Fletcher has not taken things forward? Just ask those involved. The only thing that has not made strides, it seems to me, is Croft's bowling.

Is he then seriously suggesting that selection is such a democratic process that every player gets precisely the same opportunity irrespective of ability? And that the selectors had forgotten for example that Matthew Maynard was a Glamorgan player when they drafted him in to the one-day squad earlier this summer?

Croft is not alone in his disaffection. Another spinner of longer standing - and one who has actually won games for England - has also missed out on the tour and may never play Test matches again. Phil Tufnell has taken 120 wickets for England, has had a good season for Middlesex and thinks he should have got a shout. However, his record abroad, where he has played three-quarters of his 41 Tests, is mediocre.

His response, in his newspaper column, has been to express his disappointment but also, wryly, his determination to improve and become the multi-dimensional cricketer that he believes England are seeking now. He was taking the piss, of course, but it touched a chord.

It is desperately hard to go on tour after tour and end up as drinks carrier and Croft has had three winters much like that. But he has handled this badly. Opt out by all means, but leave the way open.

Instead, in producing the bilge he did he has slammed the door shut and he is on the outside. There is nothing wrong with a cricketer raging against the dying of the light but, for goodness sake, do so with a little dignity.

webTitle: Capricorn and the BBC's national identity

fields.headline: Capricorn and the BBC's national identity
fields.standfirst: The Media Medium looks for signs in Taurean Greg Dyke's MacTaggart speech at the Edinburgh TV festival
fields.trailText: Maggie Hyde, the Media Medium, looks for signs in Taurean Greg Dyke's MacTaggart speech at the Edinburgh TV festival
fields.body:
"A new era of great British production... great British production in all genres... great British programmes." Britishness runs like a litany through Greg Dyke's MacTaggart Lecture, reiterating the hope that the BBC's distinct national identity may continue to single it out from the dozens of other channel offerings in the digital revolution.

Presumably Dyke means multi-ethnic Britishness, not Englishness, although the BBC's royal charter horoscope (January 1 1927) links strongly to the quintessential English national horoscope, the coronation of William the Conqueror on Christmas Day 1066. Both horoscopes have an identical Capricorn sun, making the BBC the cultural crown of the nation. Capricorn's are traditional, reserved, dutiful... the stuffy Beeb and the stiff upper lip.

Dyke aims to make this old Capricorn Auntie "more exciting, more gripping", but she faces the unanswerable dilemma of justifying a licence fee in an age of commercial channels. He wants universality - free, public service broadcasting - with channel genres and a creative environment for talented people. Will his strategies work?

Dyke's realistic, business-oriented Taurean nature (May 20 1947) peppers his lecture with talk of cash for this and cash for that. With the Gemini twins also strong, he should move deftly between public service broadcasting and commercial profit, from analogue past to digital future.

The immediate prospects look good. The BBC has tremendous leverage with its vast programme content through pay-on-demand and IT related services. Radical changes can be expected in June 2002 when the Sun joins hi-tech Uranus, favouring creative outsider talent.

But there's something missing. Media today has the Jupiterian role once performed by the church or the law, providing ethical and spiritual authority, but this isn't the language of modern times. Dyke's Taurean approach suggests management, not vision. To hold its archetypal place in the nation's psyche, the BBC must take this on board, with Dyke or without him.

Email the Media Medium at: maggie@companyguide.co.uk

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst: Petit Futé Guides (Distributed by Windsor Books International of Garsington, Oxford), price £8.99.
fields.trailText: Petit Futé Guides
fields.body:
A funny thing happens when you cross the strip of water separating England from France. All the details change.

From street furniture to window catches to the way they sell veg in supermarkets, everything is slightly different. Which is possibly why we keep going there.

And that's how it is with these paperback guides to the French regions. The words may have been translated into English, but somehow they remain thoroughly gallic, from their whimsical introductions ("You'll find in the following pages the heart and soul of the region. Seize them, now that you have the chance") to the adverts for local businesses that don't quite come off in English (Faïences de Quimper: "Since 1690, hand and spirit, a timeless art").

Petit Futé guides (futé means crafty like a fox) began in 1978 as the work of two French students in Nancy. They designed them for their fellow students, and from the start the idea was to flag up good, inexpensive restaurants and bars, along with all the sights worth seeing.

By 1982, the pair had covered every major city in France and were turning their attentions to the rest of the world. But in 1994, they returned to France and began producing a set of regional guides, and these form the basis of their first collection in English.

Seven titles are already available, covering Brittany, Burgundy, Provence, Bordeaux, La Rochelle and Charente Maritime, Normandy and Paris, with Geneva due out in October, Languedoc-Roussillon and Lyons in January and the Dordogne and Périgord in February.

Written by local authors, each is packed with phone numbers, opening times and up-to-date prices, as well as tips on where the French bathe and where they buy their produce.

What they lack in glossy colour photos, these guides more than make up for it in authentic local colour.

fields.headline: Free range
fields.standfirst: Comic hitman, grizzly detective, Nelson Mandela - Hollywood latecomer Morgan Freeman tells James Mottram he is busier than ever, and he likes to keep his roles varied
fields.trailText: Comic hitman, grizzly detective, Nelson Mandela - Hollywood latecomer Morgan Freeman tells James Mottram he is busier than ever, and he likes to keep his roles varied
fields.body:
He may be a film star now, but Morgan Freeman had been working quietly for 20 years before the Academy finally saw fit to nominate him for best supporting actor for his pimp in Street Smart. Two best actor nods followed - Driving Miss Daisy and The Shawshank Redemption - and roles in Unforgiven, Seven and Amistad sealed his position. This month the Memphis-born actor, now 63, turns up alongside Gene Hackman in Under Suspicion, and sparring with Chris Rock in Neil LaBute's Nurse Betty.

You play a cop in Under Suspicion and a hitman in Nurse Betty. How does that feel?

"Wonderful. It's exactly what I should be doing. My life serves me better when I have variety."

Nurse Betty is based around a woman's fantasy over a soap opera star. Were you ever a soap fan?

"No, never have been. I did a soap opera called Another World. I was on it from September 1982 until May 1984. You walk into a supermarket and some woman comes up to you and starts telling you what you should be doing, what decisions you should be making... 'What's the matter with you? Why don't you marry that girl!' They're living it."

You once said you were seldom impressed by the movies you were in. Is that true?
"I'm seldom impressed by me. When I was doing stage work, I always felt that I was larger than life because I only saw myself through the eyes of the audience. If you think I'm brilliant, then I am brilliant! Thank you, I really appreciate that. You see yourself. That gives you the lie. The disappointment can be devastating. The first time I did a movie, I went to dailies. I have not been to dailies since. I can't handle it."

In Hollywood terms, success has come late in your career. How does that make you feel?
"I don't have to deal with that. I view success the way I view it. My success started for me when I got my first job on a New York stage. I was successful. I'd arrived. From now on, it's just one step at a time. Keep working. My aim from childhood was to be a movie actor. I'd always wanted to do that, and I was extremely happy and content that I had a career in film, wherever I was. That was my ultimate aim."

How do you cope with fame?
"There is a very positive up-side to that, and a barely acceptable downside. The downside of it is that there's no such thing as privacy. All you look for is privacy. I don't want to be seen in public. It's too difficult. I dislike travelling because I gotta walk through airports. I cringe when someone says 'Hey, Morgan Freeman!' It happens all the time. I want to run when someone approaches me with a piece of paper and pencil, particularly in crowded situations. They're never going to understand you when you say, 'No, I don't do that.' It's an intrusion."

How did Under Suspicion happen?
"Gene and I said, when we were doing Unforgiven, that we must find a project to do together. He had this project he been carting round with him for 12 years. I told him, 'Let's do it'. He said, 'Well, I'm gonna have to leave it in your hands. I have been trying to get it done for years and failed.' So my production company produced it."

You are set to play Nelson Mandela. How did you come to choose that?

"It chose me. Mr Mandela finished his book. It was published that he said if he had his choice, he wanted me to play the role. I was asked by the producers if I was interested in doing it, so I got with the director Shekhar Kapur, and said I was flattered and honoured."

webTitle: Where to get culture and relaxation together

fields.headline: Where to get culture and relaxation together
fields.standfirst:
My girlfriend likes to do a lot of cultural things on holiday, whereas as I like to take a more laid-back approach and spend time on the beach. Is there somewhere in Europe that will satisfy us both? Neither of us drive.
Steven Read
fields.trailText: My girlfriend likes to do a lot of cultural things on holiday, whereas as I like to take a more laid-back approach and spend time on the beach. Is there somewhere in Europe that will satisfy us both? Neither of us drive.
fields.body:
 Venice is not well enough known for its Lido island - just 20 minutes by waterbus from the city. It faces out to the northern Adriatic across a band of yellow sandy beaches, fringed by hotels and bars. Your girlfriend can explore the cultural treasures of Venice, then join you each evening for a well-earned glass of prosecco at a beachside bar.
Jonathan Hollow

 Lindos on Rhodes. The village is a protected site, with beaches and an acropolis. Cyprus has fine mosaics at Paphos and there is a lovely beach at Coral Bay. Menorca has excellent beaches, and good museums at Mahon and Cuitedella, as well as Iron Age and Bronze Age archaeological sites.
Linnea Glynne-Rule

 Sorrento. You are within easy reach of Pompeii, Herculaneum and the archeological museum in Naples. Although much of the coastline is rocky, there are plenty of beaches to enjoy.
Caron Smith

 Go no further than Northumberland. They speak the same language as well.
Philip Scriver

fields.headline: Friends in far places
fields.standfirst: Women abroad: Is travelling alone worth the hassle? Anna Rockall finds security in a friendship group
fields.trailText: Women abroad: Is travelling alone worth the hassle? Anna Rockall finds security in a friendship group.
fields.body:
The first time I saw Cristina, she was standing at the arrivals gate at Venice airport holding a piece of paper with my name on it. All I knew about her was that she is 35, a teacher, likes hiking, is interested in Eastern philosophy, and speaks perfect English. More importantly, she loves meeting people from all around the world, learning about their country and teaching them about hers.

I'd been introduced to Cristina through Women Welcome Women World Wide (5W), an organisation that "aims to foster international friendship" by introducing women from different countries. Its members include women of all ages and types - students, housewives, professionals, married, single, retired. With 5W, you can experience other cultures, get insider knowledge of the places you visit, and make new friends. If you are nervous about travelling alone, it provides a safe and welcoming structure, and, of course, you don't have hotel bills to foot.

There is, however, the small matter of getting on with a stranger for several days. And as anyone who has used dating agencies will know, the fact that your list of hobbies matches does not necessarily mean you'll hit it off. Conversation can be a little forced, and on the drive back to Cristina's home town of Vicenza, we covered the weather (unseasonable), Italian politics (dodgy), Italian men ("traditional"), and England in general (wonderful).

Vicenza, an hour from Venice, is not a place I had ever thought of visiting, but that is one of the unexpected benefits of 5W. I found it has graceful squares with Palladian columns and arches. We strolled around town while Cristina explained any local oddities, like the half-built palace which ran out of funds, and the local university tradition of lewd comic caricatures plastered around town by celebrating graduates.

I was treated more like a long-lost best friend than a total stranger. Despite my protests, Cristina insisted on giving me her room while she slept on the sofa. She laid out breakfast for me before she went to work, sorted out my travel arrangements, and took a day off to show me around Venice. Other than taking her out for dinner to show my gratitude, there was not a lot I could do to repay so much hospitality; for the organisation to work, you must simply do your best to extend your own hospitality to other travellers.

I spent my first day in Venice on my own. St Mark's Square, the tourist hub of the City, heaved with tourists, crowding over the bridges, queueing for entrance to the Basilica, hands outstretched to feed the pigeons and staring up at the architecture. There's no denying it's an incredible place, particularly the shimmering mosaics of the Basilica, but in the summer it's enough to make a sane person flee for their life.

The next day, Cristina showed me parts of Venice I hadn't been aware of - the cramped twists and turns of the Jewish ghetto, the quiet and relatively spacious Cannaregio canal which is so much less visited than the Grand Canal, and the shops of San Leonardo. After lunch, we got lost together in the San Polo and Santa Croce area, where there are so many quiet little streets that even Cristina found herself in places she had never seen before.

But these added hours in each other's company began to highlight our differences. I began to appreciate why 5W suggests that you spend no more than a couple of nights on the first visit; although we both made the effort, it became clear that ultimately we were still two strangers with not a lot in common, whose attitudes to life were not always compatible.

Let's face it, meeting strangers can be a bit of a trial, so you have to go in with the right attitude. If you find it difficult to adapt to a different lifestyle, or annoying to hold conversations in broken English, then you would need to choose your hostesses carefully. And if you find that being a guest, weighed down with a debt of gratitude and tangled up in a web of good manners, is more of a constraint than a liberation - don't bother. The system doesn't work when it is used just for free accommodation; you have to want it to work socially.

Cristina has had 5W visitors from England and Hong Kong, and has stayed with members in England, Wales, the Shetlands and Amsterdam as well as meeting members in Vancouver and California for lunch. 5W has the world more or less covered, with 3,000 mem bers in 70 countries from Norway to Tasmania. If you are at a loose end one evening in Argentina, or looking for someone to show you around Lithuania one afternoon, 5W can supply the contact - the rest is up to you. You could even tour Australia staying with different members around the country, or - why stop there? - the whole world.

Cristina likes to travel on her own, but not to be alone. And, like many women travellers, she doesn't find it either safe or easy to meet strangers while abroad. An organisation like 5W inspires trust, and makes solo travelling an altogether friendlier experience.

Stay at home and meet the world

Regina, an Austrian member of 5W, has been providing hospitality to guests for more than 10 years in her flat situated near the centre of Vienna.

However, due to work commitments, she has never yet had the chance to visit any other members of the organisation.

"I probably wouldn't have joined if I had known I was never going to go anywhere," she says, "but I still enjoy having people to stay.

"It motivates you to do things you wouldn't normally do, and it gets you more and more interested in your own city."

She stays in touch with many of her guests, and even some 5W members who have never been able to visit her.

"Some of the women from Hungary, Russia or Ukraine, for example, simply can't afford to come here, so we just exchange letters," she says.

"I write to quite a few others, including a Japanese woman. It is wonderful to have contact with women from all backgrounds all around the world."

The practicals

For information and membership details on Women Welcome Women World Wide, write to 88 Easton St, High Wycombe, Bucks HP11 1LT, or call the office 9.30am-1.30pm Mon-Fri (tel/fax: 01494 465 441). The suggested membership donation is £20. Go, the low-cost airline from British Airways (0845 60 54321) flies to Venice from £80 return including taxes.
