fields.headline: Should same-sex marriages be legalised?
fields.standfirst: Yes says Evan Davis, author of A Fruitless Marriage, so that gay relationships get more formal recognition. No, says Terry Sanderson, writer for the Gay Times, who argues that legalisation can only bring unreasonable rules to gay relationships. Read the debate and have your say
fields.trailText:
Dear Terry,
At the risk of sounding like a conservative old so-and-so, let me say why gay relationships should get more formal recognition.
fields.body:
Dear Terry,
At the risk of sounding like a conservative old so-and-so, let me say why gay relationships should get more formal recognition.

At the moment, I am allowed a boyfriend; I can go to dinner parties with him, and maybe even the office Christmas party. Friends may even come to think of us as a couple. But relationships are one thing; marriage gives something extra. It signals a mutual expectation that our relationship is more committed and more durable than a casual fling. And it tells the world to treat us as such: to invite us to dinner parties together, to support and counsel us and even not to lead us into temptation.

And on those inevitable bad days when my partner and I feel like we want to break up, the sheer cost of having got married, and of having publicly affirmed our commitment to each other, would certainly make us think twice about taking any precipitous action. Marriage helps couples rise above the day-to-day challenges of staying together - and that can help them find fulfilment as a result.

If marriage didn't exist, someone would invent it. And most human societies have developed arrangements for binding individuals together in reasonably secure relationships. In our society, most people choose to join the marriage institution, for all its flaws. Do you really want us to be excluded?

All the best,
Evan

Dear Evan,
What exactly is marriage going to bring to your relationship that isn't there already? Rules, that's what. And as heterosexuals have discovered to their cost, swearing to abide by a lot of unreasonable rules, invented by a misogynistic and homophobic church, can bring nothing but trouble.

The fundamental advantage gay relationships have over marriage is that we can tailor them precisely to our requirements. We can make it up as we go along, change with the circumstances and go with the flow. We don't have to promise sexual exclusivity or to share our worldly goods if we don't want to. We don't have to live together if it's inconvenient or unwanted. We don't have to struggle to fit into someone else's idea of what is the "right" way to do things. We yield that flexibility at our peril.

If we want our friends and families to support and respect our relationships then we have to convince them that we are serious about each other. Only by observing our behaviour to one another will they know we are truly committed. A certificate bestowed by some institution is meaningless as a measure of our love.

Certainly marriage is still a popular institution: most people give it a shot at some time in their life. And look how many of them are now clamouring to get out of it. When judged against common sense, it's a ludicrous way to proceed. Expecting two people to stay together for 50 or 60 years is not only unreasonable, it's positively cruel.

Best wishes,
Terry

Dear Terry,
I am not arguing that marriage should be compulsory - only that it should be an option.

We both know plenty of people who want to "go with the flow", as you put it. Maybe we all do to some extent. But there are plenty of others who find the opportunity to fly more scary than staying on the ground. Some want rules to guide them and are happy to constrain their behaviour, particularly if doing so extracts a commitment from someone else to do the same.

Few of us like short-tenure housing arrangements; or temp-agency employment contracts. Why on earth should companionship arrangements be taken so much less seriously? Some flourish with freedom; others can't function until they've secured stability.

Of course, no one would argue that getting a marriage certificate guarantees a successful relationship; or that it absolves partners of having to negotiate satisfying arrangements. But it does at least tend to offer an off-the-shelf commitment on the part of both parties to invest a great deal into making the relationship work - and to try to grow together. It's not for all. But for many, the freedom you describe is more tyrannical than the spouse.

Yours,
Evan

Dear Evan,
The statistics speak for themselves - marriage doesn't work for heterosexuals, why should it work for gay people? The only thing we'd gain from institutionalising gay marriage is a lot of of painful and messy divorce. Which is not to say that I don't think long-term gay relationships are a good idea for those who want them - I've been in one myself for 20 years. But even if the government deigned to legalise some kind of same-sex marriage, we wouldn't take it up.

You say people should have the choice to marry. The problem with choice is that a lot of gay people won't have one. Many simply don't have a partner. You might say the same thing applies to heterosexuals, but special circumstances apply to gay people. There are fewer of us to go round and the odds against finding the ideal - or even a tolerable - mate are much higher than for straights.

By legalising marriage for those lucky enough to have found Mr or Ms Right, we are in danger of creating a two-tier gay community, with the "married" couples being supported and accepted while the remainder are left as outsiders, enjoying none of the privileges that legal recognition would bring to the attached.

Gay culture (and I'm not talking about the commercial exploitation that passes for entertainment on Old Compton St or Canal St) is unique. It is something that we should treasure. If we start playing by straight rules, our heritage, our colourful history and all that we share as a community will disappear into the heterosexual void. I'm all for breaking down barriers, and making progress, but there comes a moment when we must value our special place in the world. Simply giving ourselves up to become ersatz heterosexuals, when we have so much of value to contribute on our own terms, would be a shame.

Best wishes,
Terry

Dear Terry,
Gay culture is undoubtedly special, and certainly worth preserving. But as you point out in your reference to its tackier elements in the commercial scenes of London and Manchester, it is an illusion to think there is a single gay culture. There are suburban couples, gym queens, lipstick lesbians, leather-clad motorbikers, clubgoers, the works.

Making it easier for people to settle down would not threaten the vibrancy of gay life; it would enrich it, particularly for those gay people who are uncomfortable with the more superficial bar scene. As for the have-nots, who will never find Mr or Ms Right, I have little fear. Marriage - as you point out - is unlikely to become as universal a habit among same-sex couples as it is for straight ones, so the singles will not be left stranded.

Finally, you argue that we might end up with a two-tier gay community, with the non-marrieds "enjoying none of the privileges" of married couples. That's not how I see it. Gay couples should not get legal privileges. But they should not be deprived of the rights of serious relationships in immigration, joint tenancy, inheritance, hospital visiting, etc.

Some kind of legal marriage arrangement is perhaps best seen as a passport to a cluster of those "couples' rights". It would remove most of the last nonsensical legal deprivations which gay people have had to endure. You can't be against that.

All the very best,
Evan

Dear Evan,
I think our only real difference is in the use of the term "marriage". To me it comes heavily burdened with the kind of baggage that gay people should be glad they aren't required to shoulder.

I favour the French version, introduced a couple of years ago. There, any couple who live in a mutually supportive relationship can register their partnership at the local mairie. They could be a gay couple, an unmarried straight couple or even two elderly sisters. Those registering qualify for the fiscal advantages enjoyed by married couples. Nobody needs be excluded, and even those gay people who live together as dear friends, but not lovers, can benefit.

If gay couples want a "big day" type of ceremony at which they show their intimate circle that they've made a serious commitment, then that's OK with me. I love dressing up, and some of the bridal gowns these days are to die for. The lesbian and gay Christian movement will provide you with a sympathetic vicar or, if you want to leave God out of it (and He certainly wants you to leave Him out of it), the Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association have celebrants who'll see you right.

Loving, long-term partnerships that have some kind of recognition - yes. Marriage - definitely no.

Love to you and yours,
Terry

Useful links
UK lesbian & gay weddings
OutRage
Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association

fields.headline: Jungle.com snapped up by rival in £37m deal
fields.trailText: Online retailer jungle.com has been sold to offline competitor Great Universal Stores in a £37m deal, only months after the company was valued at £700m.
fields.body:
Online retailer jungle.com has been sold to offline competitor Great Universal Stores in a £37m deal, only months after the company was valued at £700m.

Jungle.com sells personal computers, computer games and music over the web, but chief executive Steve Bennett's plans for a flotation earlier this year were knocked back by the slump in internet stocks. GUS, a catalogue retail group, will integrate the company into its Argos stores, with Mr Bennett continuing to run the jungle.com business.

GUS is streamlining its portfolio after announcing last month that it would wind down its general finance division, with the eventual loss of 600 jobs. There were a further 800 job losses at the group in June, when tumbling profits forced the merger of its home shopping division with Argos.

Mr Bennett will report to Terry Duddy, chief executive of Argos and a former chief executive of PC World, which is owned by high street retailer Dixons. Analysts believe the jungle.com acquisition is part of an ambitious plan to go head-to-head with Dixons, as Argos does not sell PC computers.

Jungle.com had attracted offers from Dixons and DIY chain Kingfisher, but Mr Bennett decided GUS was a better fit for the business. The year-old company posted annual sales of £75m, but pre-tax losses were £11.4m.

Henry Blyth, retail analyst at Gilbert Eliott, said: "It is a big and interesting deal, and I am sure there will be more. We should give GUS the benefit of the doubt for now, as they know how to run this kind of business and the jungle.com products are in growth categories."

Shares in GUS rose 5.75p to 493.75p.

webTitle: Police call for scaled-down Notting Hill carnival

fields.headline: Police call for scaled-down Notting Hill carnival
fields.trailText: A scaling down of Notting Hill carnival should be considered by the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, because the event is growing beyond police control, the Metropolitan Police Assistant Commissioner Ian Johnston warned yesterday.
fields.body:
A scaling down of Notting Hill carnival should be considered by the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, because the event is growing beyond police control, the Metropolitan Police Assistant Commissioner Ian Johnston warned yesterday.

The call came after two men were murdered in separate incidents at this year's carnival, which saw an estimated 1m revellers flow through the streets of west London over the bank holiday weekend.

Mr Johnston said: "After this year's events we would like to see some modification to the carnival. It has grown so much in recent years it is time for us to reflect where we are going with it.

"It is perhaps growing beyond police resources. Some 278 crimes were committed over the two days of the event, including the murders of Greg Watson and Abdul Bhatti."

Mr Johnston emphasised he did not want to see an end to Europe's largest annual festival, but urged Mr Livingstone to make changes which could help prevent violence, such as introducing an earlier finishing time.

"The mayor should consider taking the decision about how long it lasts, who takes part and what area it covers," he said.

Police have been criticised for not intervening enough in incidents at the carnival last weekend - one report suggested two police officers were told to walk away from a scene in which a man was wielding a knife. But Mr Johnston said: "There is no question of this - on the contrary arrests are up by 84% this year and allegations of crime are up by 27%.

"Two officers on their way to another incident did come across a man with a knife. They were called away and a proper investigation was launched, and the man arrested."

webTitle: Guardian review: Stardust, The Magic Furnace and Just Six Numbers

fields.headline: Born under a wand'ring star
fields.standfirst: We are such stuff as gleams are made on.  Jon Turney  on the lessons of cosmological wonder
fields.trailText: We are such stuff as gleams are made on. Jon Turney on the lessons of cosmological wonder
fields.body:
Stardust
John Gribbin
Allen Lane, £18.99, 208pp
Buy it at BOL

The Magic Furnace: The Search for the Origins of Atoms
Marcus Chown
Vintage, £7.99, 238pp
Buy it at BOL

Just Six Numbers: The Deep Forces that Shape the Universe
Martin Rees
Phoenix, £6.99, 176pp
Buy it at BOL

The atoms in your body were forged in the nuclear fires at the heart of a nearby star, or in the exploding supernova that marked its death. This intimate connection between life on a small blue planet and creative destruction in the heavens is a fetish of popular cosmology. Twentieth-century science delivered many startling facts about the universe, but the one Joni Mitchell sang about at Woodstock is still a clear favourite with science writers. We are stardust.

It is a wondrous truth, in a slack-jawed way. And it is wondrous that some particularly complicated clumps of stardust have been able to figure out where they came from. But these facts are often taken to mean much more than this. The grand sweep of this evolutionary story has been used time and again to dispute the physicist Steven Weinberg's famous conclusion to his account of the very beginnings of the universe in The First Three Minutes: "The more the universe seems comprehensible, the more it also seems pointless."

Just telling a technical story, though, is a weak response to Weinberg's assertion. It only works if the scientific cosmology can be turned back into a religious one. But, as two books which tell the stardust story in unusual detail demonstrate, the attempt always falls short. However well we understand how the universe came to be, it does not tell us what the point is.

John Gribbin's new Stardust and Marcus Chown's The Magic Furnace: The Search for the Origins of Atoms, just out in paperback, cover much the same ground. Both use the tried-and-tested pop-science formula of recounting the formation of the elements and interweaving the story of how their stellar origins were pieced together. This is partly because otherwise the atomic narrative alone is too slender to justify a book. The American Ken Croswell did the job pretty well in a single chapter a few years ago, in The Alchemy of the Heavens. Still, it is one of the better scientific stories of the last century, uniting the physics of the microworld with the history of the cosmos.

It brings together the extraordinary understanding astrophysicists now have of what happens inside stars with cosmologists' account of the emergence of matter as the early universe expanded and cooled after the big bang. The primordial fireball generated hydrogen and helium, the lightest and still the most common elements. The longer-burning nuclear furnaces of the stars eventually cooked up the heavier ones, relatively rare but vital for making planets and, ultimately, living things. The rarer explosions of supernovae finally produced the heaviest atoms of all, and scattered the whole elemental cocktail through the far reaches of space.

Of the two efforts, Chown's version moves along more briskly, though it takes a while to get going. His tale of atoms extends back to the Greeks, but the interesting part doesn't really begin until we get to Eddington's 20th-century ideas about what happens inside stars. Even then, the confines of a discovery narrative mean that each new scientist we meet is on the verge of cracking the next puzzle. Every chapter ends with a question, and the right researcher - George Gamow, perhaps, or Fred Hoyle - pops up with the right answer in the next one. Occasional qualifications in the light of later theory hint at a messier process than this, but the overall impression is of a linear convergence on the truth.

Gribbin gives more of the twists and turns of the science, but also tells the reader too much about who did what, when. Like Chown he is admirably clear on the basics of the science, assuming almost nothing, not even ideas like "atom" or "nucleus". But Gribbin has now written 30 or 40 books on modern physics and astronomy, and there is a whiff of the production line about this one. Even his enthusiasm for these discoveries, and the ingenuity of the scientists who made them, seems rather routine.

So, nowadays, does the final chapter in the story. Stardust blasted into space bombarded the surface of the newborn Earth, bringing heavy atoms combined into complex molecules. It was not so many steps from those to the even more complex chemicals found in living cells. A billion extinct solar furnaces spread the seeds of life throughout the galaxy.

Such a benign vision of a hospitable cosmos is very appealing: everyone wants to feel wanted. The science may not reveal the hand of God, but it provides some consolation for those who miss Him. The cosmos may be unimaginably vast and awesomely old, but it is not indifferent. We are surely meant to be here. We have a role in this vast scheme of things. We are the universe becoming conscious of itself.

In fact, this rhetoric of re-enchantment has been prominent in popular science for 20 years now. The late Carl Sagan's Cosmos, a book-length riposte to Weinberg, brought it to a high pitch in 1980. For Sagan, the universe displayed a unified evolutionary process, and we were at its peak. Sagan presented science deliberately figured as myth, an effort taken further still by writers such as Brian Swimme and Thomas Berry. In their aptly titled The Universe Story, they retell the cosmic epic in would-be poetic language, even giving the various players names. The supernova that bestowed heavy elements on our corner of the galaxy is dubbed Tiamat, after a creature of middle-eastern myth from whose dismembered body heaven and earth were created.

There is none of this kind of thing in the books of Gribbin or Chown. They regard themselves as proper science writers, not myth-makers. The hint of a quasi-religious consolation is still there, but watered down. All Gribbin will say is that "life and the universe are inextricably intertwined". Chown assures us that "we are far more intimately connected to events in the cosmos than anyone dared imagine".

Yet these are very half-hearted invocations of the larger meanings of the story claimed by Sagan or Swimme, and suggest that this stream of popular science may have run its course. Astronomer Royal Martin Rees's short and admirably lucid introduction to modern cosmology in Just Six Numbers helps to show why. The outlines of the familiar elemental story are here too, along with details of another intriguing feature of the universe that has often been interpreted in much the same way. The more we understand about the forces shaping cosmic events, the more they seem selected to suit us. There is no particular reason yet known why gravity, for example, is incredibly weak compared with the forces that affect atoms at very close range. Yet if it were just a little stronger, the universe would be nasty, brutish and short-lived.

As Rees relates, there are a whole clutch of other numbers of cosmic significance that are measured rather than derived from some theory. Yet to have a cosmos that is long-lasting and can build complex structures like galaxies, planetary systems and people turns out to require just the right numbers - whether we are looking at the amount of stuff it contains, the force that holds atomic nuclei together or the smoothness of the early universe.

Using his crucial numbers, Rees builds up a compelling picture of our current understanding of the huge and ancient universe in which we dwell. He has two clear messages. Physics and cosmology are now joined in an arc of knowledge in which theories of the most fundamental particles feed directly into accounts of the development of the whole universe. And though cosmology often stretches credulity, most of the story is as soundly based as, say, the theory of the Earth in which drifting tectonic plates account for the movement of continents.

But does the cosmos itself have a message? Rees's even-handed treatment of the question shows how the moral of the stories of science is never given: it has to be supplied by their popularisers. As Rees says, we are stardust, but that is just another way of saying that everything on earth is made from nuclear ash.

· Jon Turney teaches science communication at University College, London.
fields.bodyText: Stardust John Gribbin Allen Lane, £18.99, 208pp Buy it at BOL The Magic Furnace: The Search for the Origins of Atoms Marcus Chown Vintage, £7.99, 238pp Buy it at BOL Just Six Numbers: The Deep Forces that Shape the Universe Martin Rees Phoenix, £6.99, 176pp Buy it at BOL The atoms in your body were forged in the nuclear fires at the heart of a nearby star, or in the exploding supernova that marked its death. This intimate connection between life on a small blue planet and creative destruction in the heavens is a fetish of popular cosmology. Twentieth-century science delivered many startling facts about the universe, but the one Joni Mitchell sang about at Woodstock is still a clear favourite with science writers. We are stardust. It is a wondrous truth, in a slack-jawed way. And it is wondrous that some particularly complicated clumps of stardust have been able to figure out where they came from. But these facts are often taken to mean much more than this. The grand sweep of this evolutionary story has been used time and again to dispute the physicist Steven Weinberg's famous conclusion to his account of the very beginnings of the universe in The First Three Minutes: "The more the universe seems comprehensible, the more it also seems pointless." Just telling a technical story, though, is a weak response to Weinberg's assertion. It only works if the scientific cosmology can be turned back into a religious one. But, as two books which tell the stardust story in unusual detail demonstrate, the attempt always falls short. However well we understand how the universe came to be, it does not tell us what the point is. John Gribbin's new Stardust and Marcus Chown's The Magic Furnace: The Search for the Origins of Atoms, just out in paperback, cover much the same ground. Both use the tried-and-tested pop-science formula of recounting the formation of the elements and interweaving the story of how their stellar origins were pieced together. This is partly because otherwise the atomic narrative alone is too slender to justify a book. The American Ken Croswell did the job pretty well in a single chapter a few years ago, in The Alchemy of the Heavens. Still, it is one of the better scientific stories of the last century, uniting the physics of the microworld with the history of the cosmos. It brings together the extraordinary understanding astrophysicists now have of what happens inside stars with cosmologists' account of the emergence of matter as the early universe expanded and cooled after the big bang. The primordial fireball generated hydrogen and helium, the lightest and still the most common elements. The longer-burning nuclear furnaces of the stars eventually cooked up the heavier ones, relatively rare but vital for making planets and, ultimately, living things. The rarer explosions of supernovae finally produced the heaviest atoms of all, and scattered the whole elemental cocktail through the far reaches of space. Of the two efforts, Chown's version moves along more briskly, though it takes a while to get going. His tale of atoms extends back to the Greeks, but the interesting part doesn't really begin until we get to Eddington's 20th-century ideas about what happens inside stars. Even then, the confines of a discovery narrative mean that each new scientist we meet is on the verge of cracking the next puzzle. Every chapter ends with a question, and the right researcher - George Gamow, perhaps, or Fred Hoyle - pops up with the right answer in the next one. Occasional qualifications in the light of later theory hint at a messier process than this, but the overall impression is of a linear convergence on the truth. Gribbin gives more of the twists and turns of the science, but also tells the reader too much about who did what, when. Like Chown he is admirably clear on the basics of the science, assuming almost nothing, not even ideas like "atom" or "nucleus". But Gribbin has now written 30 or 40 books on modern physics and astronomy, and there is a whiff of the production line about this one. Even his enthusiasm for these discoveries, and the ingenuity of the scientists who made them, seems rather routine. So, nowadays, does the final chapter in the story. Stardust blasted into space bombarded the surface of the newborn Earth, bringing heavy atoms combined into complex molecules. It was not so many steps from those to the even more complex chemicals found in living cells. A billion extinct solar furnaces spread the seeds of life throughout the galaxy. Such a benign vision of a hospitable cosmos is very appealing: everyone wants to feel wanted. The science may not reveal the hand of God, but it provides some consolation for those who miss Him. The cosmos may be unimaginably vast and awesomely old, but it is not indifferent. We are surely meant to be here. We have a role in this vast scheme of things. We are the universe becoming conscious of itself. In fact, this rhetoric of re-enchantment has been prominent in popular science for 20 years now. The late Carl Sagan's Cosmos, a book-length riposte to Weinberg, brought it to a high pitch in 1980. For Sagan, the universe displayed a unified evolutionary process, and we were at its peak. Sagan presented science deliberately figured as myth, an effort taken further still by writers such as Brian Swimme and Thomas Berry. In their aptly titled The Universe Story, they retell the cosmic epic in would-be poetic language, even giving the various players names. The supernova that bestowed heavy elements on our corner of the galaxy is dubbed Tiamat, after a creature of middle-eastern myth from whose dismembered body heaven and earth were created. There is none of this kind of thing in the books of Gribbin or Chown. They regard themselves as proper science writers, not myth-makers. The hint of a quasi-religious consolation is still there, but watered down. All Gribbin will say is that "life and the universe are inextricably intertwined". Chown assures us that "we are far more intimately connected to events in the cosmos than anyone dared imagine". Yet these are very half-hearted invocations of the larger meanings of the story claimed by Sagan or Swimme, and suggest that this stream of popular science may have run its course. Astronomer Royal Martin Rees's short and admirably lucid introduction to modern cosmology in Just Six Numbers helps to show why. The outlines of the familiar elemental story are here too, along with details of another intriguing feature of the universe that has often been interpreted in much the same way. The more we understand about the forces shaping cosmic events, the more they seem selected to suit us. There is no particular reason yet known why gravity, for example, is incredibly weak compared with the forces that affect atoms at very close range. Yet if it were just a little stronger, the universe would be nasty, brutish and short-lived. As Rees relates, there are a whole clutch of other numbers of cosmic significance that are measured rather than derived from some theory. Yet to have a cosmos that is long-lasting and can build complex structures like galaxies, planetary systems and people turns out to require just the right numbers - whether we are looking at the amount of stuff it contains, the force that holds atomic nuclei together or the smoothness of the early universe. Using his crucial numbers, Rees builds up a compelling picture of our current understanding of the huge and ancient universe in which we dwell. He has two clear messages. Physics and cosmology are now joined in an arc of knowledge in which theories of the most fundamental particles feed directly into accounts of the development of the whole universe. And though cosmology often stretches credulity, most of the story is as soundly based as, say, the theory of the Earth in which drifting tectonic plates account for the movement of continents. But does the cosmos itself have a message? Rees's even-handed treatment of the question shows how the moral of the stories of science is never given: it has to be supplied by their popularisers. As Rees says, we are stardust, but that is just another way of saying that everything on earth is made from nuclear ash. · Jon Turney teaches science communication at University College, London.

fields.headline: Classic con by second strings
fields.trailText: Hong Kong welcomed the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra with open arms. Thousands of people paid up to HK$240 (£21) to hear an array of "midsummer classics" from Rachmaninov's Piano Concerto No 2 to the theme music from Dr Zhivago.
fields.body:
Hong Kong welcomed the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra with open arms. Thousands of people paid up to HK$240 (£21) to hear an array of "midsummer classics" from Rachmaninov's Piano Concerto No 2 to the theme music from Dr Zhivago.

The only problem, it emerged yesterday, is that it may not have been the MPO at all but a band of enterprising musical bootleggers who sold themselves under the name.

Principal guest conductor Dimitri Yablonsky insists that the MPO was playing in Menton, Lisbon and Llivia on the precise dates last month that it was advertised to be performing in Hong Kong.

"It is a huge scandal in Moscow," he told the South China Morning Post, "very up setting." He added : "There are lots of musicians out of work in Moscow. There would be plenty of players willing to do this."

Hong Kong's cultural services department, which booked the event, says it is worried about the "potentially huge" demand for refunds.

Audiences, however, seem to have liked what they heard. The orchestra's performance of Mussorgsky's Night on the Bare Mountain was full of "exciting accelerandos contrasted with heart-stopping rubatos", said the Post's music critic.

Hong Kongers need have no worries about the authenticity of the current big performance in town. The Peking Opera Troupe of Beijing Military Region is staging the classic Chinese opera Monkey today - and no one on the mainland would dare to rip off the People's Liberation Army.

webTitle: BT rules out further big deals

fields.headline: BT rules out further big deals
fields.trailText: A beleaguered BT has admitted there will be no more big deals until disposals and flotations of its subsidiaries have pushed down its increasing debt burden.
fields.body:
A beleaguered BT has admitted there will be no more big deals until disposals and flotations of its subsidiaries have pushed down its increasing debt burden.

The company's debt is set to hit £30bn by mid-2001, but a review of potential disposals and IPOs is not expected to be completed until the end of the year. Finance director Robert Brace set a debt reduction target of £10bn after credit agency Standard & Poor's downgraded BT's rating from AA+ to A.

Possible public offerings include the Excite UK and LineOne internet ventures, with £1bn expected from the flotation of Yell, the yellow pages division. The City is more excited by the prospect of selling part of BT's mobile phone arm, which analysts say could raise as much as £10bn.

Nigel Hawkins, telecoms analyst at William de Broe, said: "The floating of the wireless division is a priority, because BT moves like a carthorse at the moment. Looking at some parts of the company, I would value it at £12 per share, but the flames of discontent are burning brightly about the BT management."

BT's shares closed up 5p at 880p, but are well below their year-high of 1500p, with analysts hanging on the announcement on IPOs and disposals.

Aside from doubts about the BT board, the stock market has not welcomed the company's decision to pay £9.3bn to increase its stake in German subsidiary Viag Interkom to 90%. BT is committed to bidding in the next four mobile phone licence auctions in Italy, Sweden, France and Switzerland after spending £9bn on licences in Britain and Germany.

"We are not pledging to stop spending more money," said a BT spokesperson. "We are not ruling out appropriate acquisitions, but we have to assess what we will IPO and what we will dispose of."

BT has denied holding recent merger talks with US telecoms giant AT&T, with Spain's Telefonica cited as a possible merger partner or even buyer.

webTitle: Capital Letters: Ian Traynor in Moscow

fields.headline: Southern promise brightens Moscow's darkest summer
fields.standfirst:
Capital Letters: Ian Traynor in Moscow

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Moscow's annual melon invasion is in full swing. In shades of green and orange, white and yellow, the fruits of central Asia have migrated north for a few brief weeks, colonising streets and parks, occupying markets, taking over railway stations, and   brightening the dark days of Russia's black summer.
fields.body:
Moscow's annual melon invasion is in full swing. In shades of green and orange, white and yellow, the fruits of central Asia have migrated north for a few brief weeks, colonising streets and parks, occupying markets, taking over railway stations, and brightening the dark days of Russia's black summer.

The invaders are a bewilderingly disparate bunch. Honeydew and cantaloupe, galia and whopping great watermelons, plus many more that have never seen the inside of a Sainsbury's. They range from grapefruit-size to the formidable 15lb marvels shaped like ballooning rugby balls.

The latter are perfection - crisp, sweet, perfumed water, though a prize specimen might set you back £7, more than a day's wages for many.

They arrive by the lorryload. The hawkers set up giant cages to confine the big balloons and dole them out by the kilo.

Isaac Babel raved about the melons in his stories of childhood in fin-de-siècle Odessa. Saparmurad Niyazov, the eternal president of Turkmenistan, has just declared a new national holiday in tribute to an export that keeps his clan in clover. From now on, Turkmens are best advised to celebrate national melon day.

The invasion is a happy hangover from the days of empire when all Soviet roads led to Moscow for the finest fruits of the 15 republics.

What the melon has in common with most other things which make life in this ramshackle, dirty metropolis more bearable - sturgeon kebabs, Azerbaijani apricots, Rima the landlady - is that it has come up to the northern city from the south.

Take the south out of Moscow and you're stuck with a city that is a drab dullard. Thanks to the input from the roughly 2m Armenians, Georgians, Chechens , Tajiks, and scores of others, the dullness is kept at bay.

Not that the Moscow authorities see it that way. The police are endemically racist towards the southerners. City hall imposes stringent registration procedures for Moscow residence rights, regularly deporting "undesirables" who are rarely ethnic Russians but almost invariably Russian citizens.

Rima, a raven-haired Armenian, has lived in the city since childhood. She's middle-aged, middle-class, a self-assured businesswoman of precisely the type that Russia needs. Last week she was hauled off a train by the police on some bureaucratic pretext and escorted under protest to the station.

"I don't like blacks," the officer hissed at her. "You're in the wrong job then, aren't you," Rima spat back.

Just another routine case of racism. The Chechen war and the recent bomb in Moscow give the authorities apparent carte blanche to harass and take bribes from the southerners.

Without them, the retail trade, markets and the catering business would collapse. To wander around the fruit and vegetable markets is to witness a clash of cultures pitting northern matriarchy against southern macho.

With few exceptions, the Russian country women (always women) selling fruit and vegetables offer the tedious European diet of insipid Dutch tomatoes, Israeli avocados and Spanish oranges. Some proper local mushrooms or raspberries might break the monotony. The prices are fixed. The sales pitch is a take-it-or-leave-it shrug.

By contrast, the Georgian and Armenian men (always men) in the market offer a riot of plants and potions from fresh pomegranate juice to serrated red leaves they call basil but which taste like aniseed. Then there are the big gnarled scarlet tomatoes to put the Dutch ones to shame. "Uzbek", the men whisper with a conspiratorial wink as though tomatoes are their best-kept secret.

To get to these goodies you have to run a gauntlet of jousting, strutting males and waste more time than you would like in haggling over the price. It's an obligatory ritual, but a contest you can never win.

They say there are half a million illegal southerners in Moscow, as well as half of Yerevan and half of Tbilisi. The melons won't be here for long, but mercifully the others are here to stay.

fields.headline: Love in a cold climate
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: Glenn has fallen in love with a girl called Courtney, who works in French's fish and chip shop on the West Quay. Apparently they bonded when he knocked a tub of curry sauce off the counter.
fields.body:
Thursday 24, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire

Glenn has been upstairs for an hour with the unopened envelope with contains his GCSE results.

I can hear him muttering to himself as I write this diary entry. The tension in the house is unbelievable. I have promised to take him to Wells-Next-The-Sea if he attains anything over a D. He has fallen in love with a girl called Courtney, who works in French's fish and chip shop on the West Quay. The lad is certainly a quick mover. We were only in Wells for an hour-and-a-half. Apparently they bonded when Glenn knocked a tub of curry sauce off the counter.

She called him a stupid wanker and that was it. They swapped e-mail addresses and have been in constant contact since. I am a little hurt that Glenn told me none of this and that I had to hear his news from my mother. Why doesn't the boy trust me with the secrets of his heart. I am his father, after all. Even David Archer has started to confide in Phil, since Ruth's chemotherapy treatment commenced.

Incidentally, I hope Mel has been kicked out of Big Brother by the time you read this. Her motives are so transparent: she obviously intends to set up a chain of massage parlours across the nation. Mark my words, Mel's Massage Parlours will soon be appearing on every high street.

1pm

Glenn has just been down and shown me his results. They are not bad, considering the boy could hardly read when he was 13. He said he would have done better if it hadn't been for the girls in his class distracting him with their good behaviour and hard work. I sympathised: my own academic ability plummeted when Pandora Braithwaite joined my class. I simply couldn't tear my eyes away from the slight swelling under her school blouse and put them on the blackboard where they belonged. It's her fault I got poor GCSE results. She has ruined my life.

Saturday 26, Plot 49, Pinewood Caravan Site, Wells-Next-The-Sea

Glenn's romance is over before it began. Courtney has been "long promised" to her second cousin, a lad called Eli, who works on the whelks and cockle store on the quay. Things are certainly feudal down here. They are but simple folk - untouched by the sophisticated outside world. It is impossible to get a Leicester Mercury. William is on the beach as I write, digging a pit in which to bury me "until you're dead day". Does he harbour subconscious patricidal desires? I don't think I'll risk getting into his pit.

Sunday 27, The Caravan

I have been consumed by caravan fever! My every waking thought is taken up with finding a method of buying a caravan of my own. I have long suspected that I may have Romany blood coursing through my veins. (I cannot stop my feet tapping when flamenco is played.) However, it is not a traditional barrel-shaped horse drawn caravan I lust for.

Specifically, it is a Willerby Westmorland; a double-glazed six-berth, with microwave and private veranda in a tasteful beige. I have worked out that it would just about fit into my mother's front garden. So, for £18,999, I could have the best of both worlds: complete independence for me and my boys together with baby-sitting services only five yards away. Why didn't I think of it before?

I have obtained the services of an independent financial adviser, a very nice man called Terry "the shark" Brighton. He is nicknamed shark because he once caught a record-breaking creature of that name while enjoying a shark fishing honeymoon in Australia with his fourth wife. I asked him to help me raise the finance for my Willerby Westmorland. Terry said no probs, but asked me to send him a cheque for £500 as a returnable deposit for his services. I won't tell my mother about the caravan just yet. It will be a lovely surprise for her.

webTitle: High note:  Channelfly.com makes US college link

fields.headline: High note:  Channelfly.com makes US college link
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Channelfly.com, the internet and music group which owns the Barfly venue in London is poised to announce its first foray across the Atlantic through a partnership with America's leading college music company.
fields.body:
Channelfly.com, the internet and music group which owns the Barfly venue in London is poised to announce its first foray across the Atlantic through a partnership with America's leading college music company.

New York-based CMJ Network has agreed to distribute Channelfly's content across the US through its CMJ.com website and CMJ New Music Review magazine.

In return, Channelfly.com will distribute CMJ's weekly top 20 chart in Britain and produce a weekly one-hour radio programme based on CMJ content for broadcast to 49 student radio stations in Britain.

Coldplay and Bare Naked Ladies are among an increasing number of well-known bands that first gained exposure through student radio.

"College radio in the States is the way you break music and the major record labels are keen to use the medium to break new acts," said ChannelFly.com's chief executive, Adam Driscoll.

Channelfly.com is already used by 300,000 16- to 24-year-olds.

webTitle: Net traders locked out of stock market

fields.headline: Net traders locked out of market
fields.standfirst:
Computer failures dog dot.com mania on the day 'Electric Henry' returned

Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of online investors were locked out of the stock market yesterday as two of the country's biggest online share dealing services broke down on one of the busiest trading days so far this year.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of online investors were locked out of the stock market yesterday as two of the country's biggest online share dealing services broke down on one of the busiest trading days so far this year.

The speculative frenzy which gripped the London market during the spring, when the excitement of amateur investors sent internet and other technology-related stocks to stratospheric levels, suddenly returned yesterday, pushing the FTSE 100 index of Britain's top companies to its highest level this year.

But computer failures at Charles Schwab and Barclays Stockbrokers, two of the country's biggest private client brokers, left their online investors unable to deal. Charles Schwab, which usually expects 75% of its trades to be conducted over the internet, failed to relaunch its website by the end of the day at 4.30pm, leaving investors to use the firm's telephone service instead, while Barclays was shut for two hours in the afternoon.

The shutdowns were unconnected and, according to the brokers, unrelated to a huge jump in trading volumes yesterday. Some 154,000 trades went through, compared with August's daily average of 75,000, as the FTSE 100 jumped 123.5 points to 6,795.

This key indicator now stands just 155 points below its all-time high, struck in December last year. The techMARK 100 index of hi-tech and biotech companies jumped more than 3%.

Brokers said the impetus for retail investors to retest the market now appears to have been a sharp improvement in sentiment on the other side of the Altantic, where worries of another rise in interest rates have abated over recent days.

A string of benign economic data from the US, capped by glowing figures on wages and employment yesterday, reinforced the belief that Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan will leave borrowing costs on hold for at least two months while the US presidential race is concluded.

In Britain there is a consensus that interest rates will be left at 6% when the Bank of England's monetary policy committee convenes next week.

Justin Urquhart Stewart, director of Barclays Stockbrokers, said: "Electric Henry, the small punter, is back. All the stocks that are moving are the familar ones."

Typical of the stocks in heavy demand yesterday was Durlacher, the specialist internet investment bank, which jumped 29%. Mr Urquhart Stewart also pointed to pure internet companies such as Affinity and QXL. "It's the usual suspects."

However, the 375p rise in Affinity to £17.50 still leaves the share well short of the £85 peak reached at the height of the internet investment frenzy this year. QXL was up 9.75p to 70p, but is worth just a tenth of its value six months ago.

Brian Winterflood, chairman of Winterflood Securities, which specialises in smaller stocks, said he was "amazed" by the amount of volume going through. "It's almost as if they've got their buying boots back on."

 Signs that the US economy may be slowing helped revive the fortunes of the battered euro yesterday after its pasting on the foreign exchanges on Thursday - which saw it hit an all-time low against the American dollar.

The euro clawed back above 90 cents from its lifetime low of 88.37 late on Thursday after new figures showed that US manufacturers cut output for the first time in 19 months in August, while the number of people in work fell by 105,000, taking the unemployment rate from 4% to 4.1%.

However, most analysts expect the euro's recovery to be short-lived. Peter Luxton at Standard & Poor's MMS said the US data should be seen as benign, despite what the headline figures suggest.

fields.headline: Rowhill Grange, Dartford
fields.trailText: The food is extremely good, if slightly rich. Presented well by a head chef who won Michelin stars in his last job.
fields.body:
Address: Rowhill Grange, Wilmington, Dartford, Kent, DA2 7QH.

Tel: 01322 615136.

Web address: www.rowhillgrange.com

First impressions: A country house set in spacious grounds - a tad nouveau, but comfortably far from the hubbub.

What are the rooms like: All individually named - hibiscus, mulberry, that kind of thing - they are comfy and spacious. Perhaps a bit chintzy, but they're fully equipped and made for relaxing.

The bed test: The room's best feature. A four-poster with good, solid mattress and a fantastic, quilt-like mattress cover. Dreamy.

The bathroom test: Power shower, bath with instant hot water. Lots of free creams, and best of all - fluffy dressing gowns and slippers.

The restaurant: The food is extremely good, if slightly rich. Presented well by a head chef who won Michelin stars in his last job. Service a shade eccentric from a staff who barely speak English, but the artichoke heart starter was a winner and the pear tatin pudding a treat.

What is there to see within walking distance? Don't bother. Keep your bathrobe on - everybody else does - and head for the spa. Masseurs may be a bit feeble for those who like a real pummelling,but otherwise it's a fast-track to Zen-like relaxation. Jet-bath yourself with oils, hop from the Jacuzzi to the sauna and fantasise that you're in Rome in the age of decadence.

What is there to see within a 10-minute drive? The M25. Don't laugh, the big advantage is that it's such a quick getaway from London.

How much a night? Doubles from £154.

Would you go back? As soon as I feel like letting my hair down for a weekend of indulgence, I'll know where to go.

fields.headline: England's revolution almost complete
fields.trailText: You can see the London Eye clearly from The Oval, and if you stare really hard you can see it inch around on its axis. On the pitch, however, the wheel is turning more perceptibly in England's favour.
fields.body:
You can see the London Eye clearly from The Oval, and if you stare really hard you can see it inch around on its axis. On the pitch, however, the wheel is turning more perceptibly in England's favour.

Today's Calypso collapse - five wickets for seven in 22 balls - was particularly special because it encompassed Brian Lara's first golden duck in Tests. Lara strode out, all superstar confidence, playing an immaculate defensive shot to the crowd. Thirty seconds later he had to turn on his heel, outwitted by a searing delivery from Craig White which removed his leg stump.

White's revelatory season just gets better and better. He zipped in even more whippily today than he did at Headingley - and on a less responsive pitch - perhaps inspired by the presence of his mother, brother, sister, sister-in-law and nephew who all fly back to Melbourne tomorrow. He has now taken five wickets in an innings in successive Tests. When asked at the press conference why, or from where, he had suddenly found this zing, he replied, "I feel very comfortable in the team situation. I know that my team-mates rate me and that they expect me to get wickets."

Maybe this statement will provide some comfort to Nasser Hussain, whose batting is stuck in such a mire that he will need to find some seven-league boots from somewhere to jump out of it. His pair was the first by an England captain since Ian Botham in 1981.

He had somehow survived four balls from Curtly Ambrose and ten from Courtney Walsh before finally being put out his misery by Nixon McLean's third ball of the day and, to be honest, it was a bit of a relief. In 2000 Hussain has scored 148 Test runs in 13 innings, at an average of 11.

To make matters worse, by the time Graham Thorpe had dragged himself out to the middle, slow step by slow step, three lights were on the scoreboard and the umpires were offering the light. Two minutes later the heavens opened. Perhaps he needs to write this year off as the last of the nasty nineties and join David Gower in insisting that the new millennium doesn't begin until January 1 2001.

After the first partnership of the match added 159, the next 19 only managed 247. England are now 212 ahead with eight wickets in hand. If this game follows its likely course, England's 31-year-wait to recapture the Wisden Trophy is nearly over.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Beatification angers Jews and liberals
fields.standfirst: Pope puts ill-matched forerunners on the path to sainthood
fields.trailText: Ignoring protests from Jews and liberal Roman Catholics, the Pope will beatify one of his predecessors, Pius IX, today, despite the fact that he is accused of anti-semitism, kidnapping and persecution.
fields.body:
Ignoring protests from Jews and liberal Roman Catholics, the Pope will beatify one of his predecessors, Pius IX, today, despite the fact that he is accused of anti-semitism, kidnapping and persecution.

Putting Pius IX on the road to sainthood will reopen old wounds and put an unbearable strain on Jewish-Catholic relations, the Pope's critics have warned.

The last pope-king, who reigned from 1846 to 1878, Pius IX was notorious for herding Rome's Jews into a ghetto, forcibly baptising their children, and limiting their education and employment rights. At his funeral Italian liberals tried to throw his body into the Tiber.

Ultra-conservatives in the Vatican are believed to have championed his nomination to counter the simultaneous beatification of John XXIII, who ushered in the liberalisation of the Roman church with the second Vatican council in 1962.

Under the headline "A beatification too far", the British Catholic weekly the Tablet said it was a political attempt to provide a conservative and reactionary counterweight.

Liberals complained that a pontiff who executed criminals and attacked human rights was being held up as a role model.

Pius IX issued the Syllabus of Errors - 80 points denouncing the separation of church and state, progress, and modern civilisation - and promulgated the dogmas of papal infallibility and the Virgin Mary's immaculate conception.

Most of the 200,000 people expected in St Peter's Square will be honouring John XXIII, revered in Italy as the "good pope" who breathed fresh air into the church.

Scholars are uncertain how John Paul II will combine tributes to predecessors said to be popes apart.

Traditionalists praised the noble-born Pius IX for his courage in defending the church from the tumult of revolutionary Europe, which effectively made him a prisoner in the Vatican. He should not be judged by standards outside his time, they argued.

Jewish groups will hold a candle-light demonstration in Rome tonight, but they are not expected to try to disrupt tomorrow's ceremony.

Pius IX is notorious for snatching the six-year-old Jewish boy Edgardo Mortara from his family in Bologna in 1858, four years after he was baptised by a maid who feared for his soul.

The case became a cause celebre, but appeals by world leaders failed to move Pius, who raised Edgardo as his own son. He became a priest and died in 1940, allegedly mentally scarred.

Elena Mortara, Edgardo's great-great niece, said Pius had caused profound suffering in her family and community by actions regarded as shocking even in his own time.

Elan Steinberg of the World Jewish Congress questioned why John Paul, who has devoted much of his 22-year pontificate to reaching out to Jews, should now choose to undermine reconciliation.

"We have a paradox here," she said.

Seymour Reich, chairman of the International Jewish Committee for Interreligious Consultations, said: "Today, after almost a century and a half, the Italian Jewish community remains embittered by that assault on Judaism and parenthood.

"If saintliness is seen as the goodness, wisdom and courage to behave righteously and right wrongs regardless of when they occur, then Pius IX's conduct falls far short of saintliness."

A proposal to beatify Pius IX in 1985 was shelved after two senior cardinals and official biographers suggested that he was unsuitable.

But in the Italian media, criticism of his beatification has been swamped by enthusiasm for the rapid beatification of the peasant-born John XXIII. Ribbons and balloons festoon his home town, Bergamo.

Insiders said the Vatican wanted to twin his beatification with the wartime Pius XII, but the plan was abandoned after renewed controversy over his failure to speak out against the Holocaust.

According to one diplomat, Israel has not intervened in the case of Pius IX because it suspects that there will be another attempt to beatify Pius XII and wants to keep its powder dry.

John Paul II's eagerness to supply Catholic role models has produced what critics call a "saint factory". Since his election in 1978 he has beatified and canonised more than 1,200 candidates: more than all his 20th century predecessors combined.

fields.headline: High Holborn, London
fields.standfirst: High Holborn opted for a quiet opening. Its menu, too, has an unfussy charm. The cooking, however, is anything but modest, says Matthew Fort. In fact, it's brilliant
fields.trailText: High Holborn opted for a quiet opening. Its menu, too, has an unfussy charm. The cooking, however, is anything but modest, says Matthew Fort. In fact, it's brilliant
fields.body:
High Holborn slipped into this world with very little fuss. No opening party (or, if there was one, I was not invited, no celebrity boffing, no magazine profiles, no hullaballoo. One day it was a building site on a rather undistinguished stretch of the rather undistinguished High Holborn, the next there it was, open and ready for business. This quiet modesty extends to the outside of the restaurant. So well-behaved is it, you could easily miss it. But the modesty stops at the front door.

The inside is a riot of colour and designery statement, with banquette seats in British racing green racked up the walls like inner tubes piled on top of one another, with lights like huge inflamed gonads dangling from the ceiling, and with wall colourings that follow the new fashionable theory of opposing colours, or clash, as we used to call it. If all that sounds unpleasant, it isn't. Baffling, perhaps, but fun.

The stern elegance and impeccable cleanliness of the lavatories is deeply reassuring. The service, too, is very good: bespoke-tailored, smiling, efficient and charming.

Before I arranged to meet Pantagruel there, I had already registered that the chef is David Cavalier, a talented cook whom life has not treated as kindly as it might. Consequently, it is some time since the wider public have been able to enjoy his food. Now we can - and, I must say, it has been worth queuing up for.

I had, in fact, already eaten in High Holborn the week before - the week it opened, in fact - which is not my usual practice. On that occasion, I had a salad of pigs' trotters and new potatoes with sauce gribiche and then smoked fillet of whiting (or "merlan", as the menu insists on calling it) with bubble and squeak, poached egg and hollandaise sauce, followed by a carpaccio of pineapple with coconut sorbet. On that occasion, my companion, Clothilde, made short work of asparagus with a poached egg and a truffle dressing, and then of fillet of lamb with courgettes, asparagus and broad beans, ending with a lemongrass and raspberry crème brlée on the reasonable grounds that crème brlée and raspberries are two of her favourite foods in the whole world.

So, by the time that Pantagruel and I had put to the sword duck rillette, watercress and mustard salad and a fish soup with rouille, grated cheese and crotons; roast mackerel with spiced chickpeas and best end of lamb with aubergine and courgette tian; and peach Melba and the carpaccio of pineapple again - all off a generous and splendid menu du jour - I had a pretty good feel for Cavalier's way with ingredients. First off, the menu descriptions are as brief and to the point as the dishes are elegant and sophisticated. The rillettes were as advertised, but glazed with a splash of light béarnaise and layered between two tiny poppadoms spotted with mustard seeds. Well, blow me, this isn't the hunky, hefty stuff you get from your local traiteur; it's light, delicate, yet knee-tremblingly rich. The salad alongside was a thoughtful mixture of leaves, with a sweetish dressing that insinuated itself to the duck with ingratiating charm.

The pigs' trotter salad that I'd had a few days earlier was a similarly refined treatment of a hefty classic, which lost nothing and gained much in translation. The poached trotter had been boned out, formed into a round sausage held in its own jelly, sliced and laid on top of the potatoes with a rich and pungent sauce splattered around. So you got a bit of mild meat in a mild jelly, the firm and earthy potatoes all lubricated with a sauce that combined unctuousness and acid in equal parts.

Combining a highly characterised, not to say oily, fish with chickpeas spiced with chilli; the deft cooking of the lamb; the adroit seasoning of all dishes; the way in which vegetables were built into the totality of the dishes; the nifty reworking of classic combinations; and, above all, the unfaultable technique, which meant that each element of each dish was made as it should be (the fish soup was an exemplar for others to follow, if they can)... I mean, when was the last time you had a serious peach Melba, or even hollandaise?

This care and consideration reached right through to the puddings. The carpaccio of pineapple was an exceptionally satisfying and clever variation on a well-worn theme, the texture and tartness of the fruit lending itself brilliantly to the treatment (and something you could do at home if you have a slicing machine). None of this is revolutionary stuff. It fits easily within the canon of French cooking. It is French in its technique and tastes. Such intelligence and technical mastery are quite exhilarating in the midst of so many examples of extravagant, ill-assorted experimentation.

Lunch with Pantagruel came to £75.50. The eating bit took up £46 - that is, two set-price lunches at £23 for three courses - and £20 went on an outstanding bottle of Corbières (the wine list is building up a strong contingent of decently priced regional French wines in the hands of the disarming sommelier, Frédéric Brugues). The usual bits and pieces accounted for the rest.

If, as claimed by Anthony Bourdin recently, you can judge a restaurant by its loos, High Holborn should do very well. On balance, though, I think Cavalier's cooking will have a bigger part to play in its success

So, by the time that Pantagruel and I had put to the sword duck rillette, watercress and mustard salad and a fish soup with rouille, grated cheese and crotons; roast mackerel with spiced chickpeas and best end of lamb with aubergine and courgette tian; and peach Melba and the carpaccio of pineapple again - all off a generous and splendid menu du jour - I had a pretty good feel for Cavalier's way with ingredients. First off, the menu descriptions are as brief and to the point as the dishes are elegant and sophisticated. The rillettes were as advertised, but glazed with a splash of light béarnaise and layered between two tiny poppadoms spotted with mustard seeds. Well, blow me, this isn't the hunky, hefty stuff you get from your local traiteur; it's light, delicate, yet knee-tremblingly rich. The salad alongside was a thoughtful mixture of leaves, with a sweetish dressing that insinuated itself to the duck with ingratiating charm. The pigs' trotter salad that I'd had a few days earlier was a similarly refined treatment of a hefty classic, which lost nothing and gained much in translation. The poached trotter had been boned out, formed into a round sausage held in its own jelly, sliced and laid on top of the potatoes with a rich and pungent sauce splattered around. So you got a bit of mild meat in a mild jelly, the firm and earthy potatoes all lubricated with a sauce that combined unctuousness and acid in equal parts. Combining a highly characterised, not to say oily, fish with chickpeas spiced with chilli; the deft cooking of the lamb; the adroit seasoning of all dishes; the way in which vegetables were built into the totality of the dishes; the nifty reworking of classic combinations; and, above all, the unfaultable technique, which meant that each element of each dish was made as it should be (the fish soup was an exemplar for others to follow, if they can)... I mean, when was the last time you had a serious peach Melba, or even hollandaise? This care and consideration reached right through to the puddings. The carpaccio of pineapple was an exceptionally satisfying and clever variation on a well-worn theme, the texture and tartness of the fruit lending itself brilliantly to the treatment (and something you could do at home if you have a slicing machine). None of this is revolutionary stuff. It fits easily within the canon of French cooking. It is French in its technique and tastes. Such intelligence and technical mastery are quite exhilarating in the midst of so many examples of extravagant, ill-assorted experimentation. Lunch with Pantagruel came to £75.50. The eating bit took up £46 - that is, two set-price lunches at £23 for three courses - and £20 went on an outstanding bottle of Corbières (the wine list is building up a strong contingent of decently priced regional French wines in the hands of the disarming sommelier, Frédéric Brugues). The usual bits and pieces accounted for the rest. If, as claimed by Anthony Bourdin recently, you can judge a restaurant by its loos, High Holborn should do very well. On balance, though, I think Cavalier's cooking will have a bigger part to play in its success

fields.headline: Trail of the unexpected
fields.standfirst: Self-sowers bring welcome surprises. But watch them very closely, says Christopher Lloyd - or they might take over
fields.trailText: Self-sowers bring welcome surprises. But watch them very closely, says Christopher Lloyd - or they might take over.
fields.body:
Self-sown plants are a joy in our own gardens (you rarely meet them in public), but it has to be understood that, when any plant makes itself comfortable, you have to watch it. And watching it probably means eliminating 99 out of 100 seedlings.

Think, for instance, how messy self-sown fennel is at this time of year. And it is a tough-rooted plant; an effort to dig out once it has a hold. It's the same with Alchemilla mollis: charming when its young leaves unfold in spring and its lime-green flowers first appear, it will sow itself into all sorts of unexpected places, such as under a bench. But its aim is to take over completely, and it often succeeds. By August, it looks disgusting, its flowerheads brown and trodden on. Again, it is tough to extract.

My own garden is full of the wild teazel, which has been flowering these past few weeks, but quickly turns brown. Great presence though its structure has, too many skeletons in the garden become depressing. We shall extract a good many of them, but the rest will be welcome in winter, when dead heads are an asset. They will be visited by goldfinches and, given the weather, comically capped by snow. Meantime, the deep green rosettes of next year's crop are already in place, and need thinning (99 hundredths of them). Some look good at a border's margin, and they like it there, where they find minimal competition. I'll leave some of those; tall though they grow (a good 2m), their open structure does not block the view.

Eryngium giganteum, widely known as 'Miss Willmot's Ghost', was at its best in July, with stiff, silvery bracts forming a ruff around the dome of its sea-greeny-blue florets. In August, it declines to a raddled parchment shade, and needs removing. If the ground is soft, after a storm, say, you can pull the tap root out. Otherwise, take the line of least resistance and cut as low as you can, leaving the root to rot. Next year's seedlings are there, though not always placing themselves where you would most like to see them. Thin them rigorously; if overcrowded, they may not flower at all or, if they do, as rather miserable specimens.

One of my great stand-bys is Lychnis coronaria - that of the magenta moon-flowers supported by grey-felted stems and leaves. Plants will generally last in good health for a couple of flowerings, but are then greatly weakened. You can easily see which of them should be removed at this stage. Those that you save can be cut back so as to leave their basal, leafy rosettes only. This lychnis will present you with some amazing colour combinations. Before you dub them outrageous and insupportable clashes, just stop and think. Perhaps that clash is rather exciting, where it is occurring, after all. In front of a scarlet crocosmia such as 'Lucifer', say, or with the yellow of Coreopsis verticillata. This, although a strong yellow, contains just a hint of green, which makes all the difference.

I have a lot of giant oenothera, the one named O. glaziouana (2m). An evening primrose whose new crop of flowers opens quite late in the evening, they are often generous next morning, remaining in good condition for several hours, especially if the weather is dull. With me, this displays itself to perfection by placing itself at various levels: in the floor of the sunken garden, in the retaining wall around it and in the borders above. So it presents, from the other side of the sunken garden, a curtain of yellow goblets. I could hardly have organised that. But they are running to seed now, and are frighteningly prolific, so I must watch out.

A quieter, yet stylish self-sower is the hardy perennial papyrus, Cyperus eragrostis (C. vegetus). Above naked stems (0.7m), it splays out into a green rosette of bracts and a cushion of green flowers. Not showy, this has considerable presence, though it can look weedy if self-sown in quantity. A specimen that Fergus particularly liked put itself near to the fringe of a huge, carpeting Juniperus sabina 'Tamariscifolia'. I think the cyperus is succumbing to engulfment, but it is good in shallow water, too, and I like a few in paving cracks.

Many euphorbias self-sow. With the biennial Euphorbia stricta (0.4m), you depend on it to do so.

It makes an airy, lime-green inflorescence and, if the situation is a bit hungry, as in a paving crack, the plant stems and pedicels will be attractively red. When E. characias self-sows, you are liable to get a whole lot of rubbish, with unnecessarily dull green inflorescences, whereas good strains of the subspecies wulfenii are bright lime green, verging on yellow. One of the more exciting self-sowers is the shrubby E. mellifera. It has large, evergreen rosettes of important-looking foliage. When this flowers (the blooms smell strongly of honey), the resulting seeds, on ripening, are ejected to a distance of several metres, so self-sowns may astonish you by their positioning. This species is not entirely hardy, but may reach a height of two or three metres. But I think young, unflowered plants are the most handsome

webTitle: How to bring first-class cricket up-to-date

fields.headline: How to bring first-class cricket up-to-date
fields.trailText: There are dozens of big-time sporting competitions in the world. Baseball, tennis, football of many codes, basketball, motor racing, golf, athletics, swimming, horse racing. They are all competing for the sports fan's time and money.
fields.body:
There are dozens of big-time sporting competitions in the world. Baseball, tennis, football of many codes, basketball, motor racing, golf, athletics, swimming, horse racing. They are all competing for the sports fan's time and money.

Cricket is one sport that has not kept up with the modern sports fan. Continuing to be propped up by one-day cricket, first-class and Test cricket has made no attempt to catch the eye or make itself accessible for the casual fan. The advances in presentation, promotion and formatting of the one-day game have not crossed over to the longer format as it should have. In the way are the 'purists' who want to keep the game as it was when they were young, around the Second World War.

It's about time the game caught up with the rest of the world, to catch the eye of the fans, entice them to come and give them a reason to come back. Changes must be made to presentation, spectator convenience and context.

Presentation is easy to solve. Use a white ball for first-class cricket. Make a white ball visible over 80 overs. For the first 40 overs, use a standard white ball. For the next 40 use a standardised "old" ball, which has rougher leather and flatter stitching, but is otherwise a bright, lacquered brand new ball. Easy to see, and plays like the real thing. Now you can play at night, wear coloured uniforms, show the crowd who they paid money to see. Grab the attention of the casual observer who has come to see Tendulkar or Warne or the new kid they've been hearing about. A big portion of gate earnings would surely come from the part-time fan - it's most important they feel at home too.

Next, shorten the matches. Five days, over one working week, the weekend and the next week is asking too much of the public when it can follow other games much more easily. Taking a young family to sit for seven or more hours is asking too much. First-class and Test cricket could easily take the following form:

- Three-day matches of four playing hours each, or 180 overs.

- Eleven-a-side still, but to win a match, a side has to score more runs, and, over two innings, dismiss 13 (as against 20) batters. (Everybody has a bat before anybody bats for a second time.) Draws are still possible.

- First innings closes after 60 overs or a declaration, whichever is first.

Making the game shorter and easier to schedule and promote makes it more attractive to everyone involved.

Matthew Engel's proposed Test World Championship is a great idea. Every four years, a Pura Cup-style final should be played to decide the winner. A Championship should conclude the year after the one-day World Cup. Also, play the first match of a Test series abroad or inland - Malaysia, Singapore, Holland, USA. Test matches rather than one-day tournaments. India or Pakistan v West Indies might do well in Florida.

The current match-fixing scandals are part of a larger problem of cricket refusing to yield to the modern sporting and global landscape. It is about time it budged.

Michael Gray, 23, lives in Australia
