webTitle: 'Knowing English does not make you a good doctor'

fields.headline: 'Knowing English does not make you a good doctor'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Imtiaz Ahmed has been working as a senior house officer in British hospitals since July 1999. He is a foreign doctor, part of a group of people whose "English language skills are not up to scratch and [whose] patients are suffering as a result", according to statements last week from the shadow health minister Liam Fox.
fields.body:
Imtiaz Ahmed has been working as a senior house officer in British hospitals since July 1999. He is a foreign doctor, part of a group of people whose "English language skills are not up to scratch and [whose] patients are suffering as a result", according to statements last week from the shadow health minister Liam Fox.

Yet, as he speaks from the ward of the department of medicine for elderly people at Whipps Cross hospital in London, Dr Ahmed is the most articulate of men. Like his colleagues from overseas, Dr Ahmed has had to pass rigorous tests to work as a senior house officer in a British hospital. And his English is better than many of those in the beds around him.

Originally from Bangladesh, where he studied medicine in English, the young doctor dismissed Dr Fox's comments - the MP and former GP said: "It is quite clear from talking to patients and doctors that the communications skills of many overseas-registered doctors are simply inadequate" - as "rubbish".

What concerns Dr Ahmed and many other overseas doctors is the impact such statements will have on doctors and students abroad who wish to come to Britain to experience working in the NHS. He said: "Dr Fox's comments will demoralise overseas students if they see that a major party thinks that about them."

Stringent

In its national plan for health, published last month, the government promised 7,000 more consultants and 2,000 more GPs before 2004. With a lack of trained British personnel, some of these places will have to be filled by foreign doctors.

Britain has much more stringent English language tests than America and elsewhere. Overseas doctors wishing to practice in the UK must first pass the international English language testing system, where students have to pass sections in listening, reading, writing and speaking. Set by the British Council, doctors must achieve a higher pass rate than that needed in other sectors.

After passing the tests, doctors must take the exceptionally difficult professional and linguistic assessment board (PLAB) test, set by the General Medical Council. A pass allows limited registration to practice medicine in the UK.

At the end of a week in which their qualifications and language were the focus of debate, foreign doctors have said that Dr Fox's remarks would not encourage young doctors to work in a system already perceived to be racist by many of the 23,000 or so overseas doctors working within it.

Surendra Kumar, chair of the Overseas Doctors Association, said: "If these 23,000 doctors weren't here today there would be no NHS. Dr Fox has confused and misled the issue by putting all foreign doctors in one melting pot."

Because of EU legislation providing for mutual recognition of qualifications, doctors who are citizens of member states are entitled to register in other member states. There are no controlling mechanisms or checks on their language skills.

Dr Kumar said: "I have known young Spanish, German, and other European doctors walking round wards with a dictionary trying to interpret what is wrong with a patient. If that is the sort of language difficulty that exists then I have no doubt what Dr Fox says, that it will put patients at risk. But I have no doubt his comments were targeted at south Asian doctors.

"For those doctors coming from outside the EU, they have been trained in English, using the same textbooks as their British counterparts. In spite of all this they have to go through very thorough tests before they can work here. Recently, the GMC conducted an audit of 55 British doctors, asking them to sit the PLAB test. Only two passed."

Sam Everington, a GP based in Stepney, east London, who has studied racism within the NHS, said he has observed "racial discrimination at every stage of a [foreign] doctor's career".

Aneez Esmail, who is based at Manchester University's department of general practice and has also investigated NHS racism, said: "I speak better English than Liam Fox does. He is referring to a time in the early 1970s when the NHS was really short of doctors and imported them en masse.

"The country needed them and they came in; if they felt the language was a secondary issue and they wanted the knowledge then that's a choice that they made at the time."

Sitting in his surgery in Bow, east London, Selladurai Shanmugadasan is disturbed by the aspersion cast on him and his colleagues. Dr Shan, as he is known to his patients, came to the UK from Sri Lanka in 1981. He worked in 10 British hospitals after passing his PLAB test, which he said was "very stringent".

Asset

He feels the door is gradually being closed on non-European doctors."A lot of people who talk against foreign doctors were delivered by them and looked after by them as a child. Foreign doctors are highly intelligent people coming here and they are an asset to this country. A lot of the postgraduate exams they pass in their country are more difficult to pass than exams here.

"It's cheaper to have a foreign doctor working in this country than to train a British doctor. There's a big manpower crisis in this country and the NHS will be in trouble if people like Liam Fox continue to lash out against foreign doctors."

What bothers Dr Shan is the idea that the ability to speak good English makes a person a good doctor. "You cannot automatically say that every person born in this country and trained here and qualified actually listens and understands their patients. The doctor/patient relationship is very complicated, you need to have character and feel to help people. Just because you know English doesn't make you a good doctor."

Language check-up

A sample question from the academic writing sections says:
Present a written argument or case to an educated reader with no specialist knowledge of the following topic.

The first car appeared on British roads in 1888. By the year 2000 there may be as many as 29m vehicles on British roads.

Alternative forms of transport should be encouraged and international laws introduced to control car ownership and use.

What do you think?

Give reasons for your answers.

You should write at least 250 words.

You should use your own ideas, knowledge and experience and support your arguments with examples and relevant evidence.

A sample from the speaking section:
You are hoping to go to college in Newcastle. Imagine that the interviewer comes from Newcastle and ask him or her questions to find out as much as you can about the town.

Find out about: weather; size; accommodation; shops; transport: entertainment

fields.headline: Media forces Danish far right to scale down anti-euro campaign
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The far-right Danish People's party, one of the country's most vociferous opponents of the euro, is to scrap a major advertising campaign ahead of this month's referendum because it fears it is alienating leftwing voters who loathe its policies as much as they detest the single currency.
fields.body:
The far-right Danish People's party, one of the country's most vociferous opponents of the euro, is to scrap a major advertising campaign ahead of this month's referendum because it fears it is alienating leftwing voters who loathe its policies as much as they detest the single currency.

The DPP has, in the minds of many Danes, become closely associated with the campaign to reject the euro in a referendum on September 28.

However, the media have seized on other of its policies, such as the repatriation of refugees, castration of paedophiles and "Denmark for the Danes", creating a welter of embarrassing publicity.

The leftwing Socialist People's party and grassroots organisations are also pushing for a No vote in the crucial referendum but their media profile has been much lower.

The DPP will make a final push for a Nej to the euro this weekend at their annual congress, where the maverick Tory MEP and Daily Telegraph leader writer Daniel Hannan will be the guest of honour. But party officials conceded yesterday that this would be their last big campaign effort.

"A lot of leftwingers are against the EU and the euro but if we are too aggressive, especially in the newspapers and on TV, perhaps we will deter them," Jens Wibeck, a DPP official, said. "We don't want to be too provocative and the press is always on our backs. Too much focus has been on us." The DPP's leadership has found the media attention uncomfortable and its governing board is to step into the shadows after this weekend's congress.

A planned nationwide television and newspaper advertising campaign has been pulled and the DPP's outspoken leader, Pia Kjaersgaard, is expected to curb her more colourful outbursts.

Holger Nielsen, leader of the Socialist People's party, yesterday told the Guardian he welcomed the DPP's change of tack but questioned its motives. "If they had been very active it could have been a problem," he said. "My own opinion is that they will save the money they would have spent on an ad campaign and spend it on refugee questions. That's the real reason."

An opinion poll yesterday gave the Yes camp a 4% lead over the No camp, but the vote is still too close to call, even though the Danish government, most political parties, the media and big business have backed a Yes vote.

webTitle: Tories fight back over Vaz swipe at Eurosceptic press

fields.headline: Tories fight back over Vaz swipe at Eurosceptic press
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz's attack on the rightwing British press for its "xenophobic" coverage of the European Union prompted a backlash from the Conservatives yesterday. They accused the minister for Europe of "whingeing" and misleading the British people.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz's attack on the rightwing British press for its "xenophobic" coverage of the European Union prompted a backlash from the Conservatives yesterday. They accused the minister for Europe of "whingeing" and misleading the British people.

Mr Vaz blamed Eurosceptic newspapers such as the Sun and the Daily Telegraph for misrepresenting government policy on the single currency and turning voters against the EU with scare stories which were more fiction than fact.

But the Tories accused ministers of misleading the British people about Labour's true intention, which was to take Britain into the single currency.

Mr Vaz made his charge in a speech to business leaders in Cardiff aimed at rallying public support for Europe in the face of opinion polls showing dwindling support for Britain's membership of the EU.

Mr Vaz told the Cardiff chamber of commerce: "All too often we see articles and opinion pieces that either misrepresent policy or deal with fiction rather than fact. By politicising straightforward issues or even spreading anti-EU propaganda, they are clouding the debate."

The shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, called for the prime minister, the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and Mr Vaz to "come clean" about their real desire to scrap the pound.

He said: "Keith Vaz's whinge about the media just shows that Labour will do anything to deflect attention from their true agenda to scrap the pound and drag Britain into a single European superstate by stealth."

Speaking in an interview ahead of yesterday's speech, Mr Vaz said: "We should be putting the facts before the British people and that is not happening at the moment."

He accused the Daily Telegraph and other rightwing newspapers of "pumping up negative news and playing down the positive."

But the Daily Telegraph editor, Charles Moore, said the government was responsible for concealing the truth about entry to the single currency. "There are many people in favour of membership of the EU who are against abolishing the pound. This is constantly obscured by the government."

The leaking of a Labour party political broadcast to the Tories sparked a war of words yesterday. The broadcast, the Real Tory Manifesto, which claims that Tory spending plans will mean £16bn in cuts to public services, was due to be screened in Scotland on Monday evening.

Labour officials were forced to deny government involvement in planting the video. But John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, said: "If we get this kind of attention for a party political broadcast I will be leaking it myself next time."

The Tory leader, William Hague, claimed the government was "trying to cover up its own failure to deliver on its promises".

webTitle: Castro to add his voice to record-setting UN summit

fields.headline: Castro to add his voice to record-setting UN summit
fields.trailText: The Cuban president, Fidel Castro, created a flurry of excitement yesterday by signalling his intention to attend next week's UN millennium summit in New York, the biggest gathering of world leaders in history.
fields.body:
The Cuban president, Fidel Castro, created a flurry of excitement yesterday by signalling his intention to attend next week's UN millennium summit in New York, the biggest gathering of world leaders in history.

While his presence will add unpredictability to proceedings, it will also attract demonstrations from Cuban exiles still seething from the Elian Gonzales immigration row.

The leaders of more than 150 of the 188 countries that make up the UN are scheduled to attend the summit. Mr Castro had been thought unlikely to attend.

The Cuban foreign ministry said yesterday: "This morning, we communicated to the US government that the delegation would be presided by comrade Fidel. Now, everything depends on the attitude taken by the US government."

Anti-Castro forces in the US immediately called for him to be denied a visa. But a spokesman at the Cuba desk of the US state department indicated last night that permission will be granted.

Mr Castro, 74, will provide an alternative voice at a summit that is shaping up to provide worthy resolutions on peacekeeping and poverty, but avoid the hard decisions needed to do anything about them.

The three-day summit, which begins on Wednesday, will almost certainly endorse a UN declaration setting out goals for poverty-reduction and improved peacekeeping. The declaration is a condensed version of a speech made earlier this year by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, in which he set out the aims of the UN for the 21st century.

The aims include halving within 15 years the 22% of the world's population now existing on less than a dollar a day. The same timetable will be set for halting and reversing the spread of Aids.

Tony Blair, in a speech on Wednesday, will throw Britain's weight behind a proposal against a permanent UN standing army, opting instead for a permanent high command, which, in theory, would mean a faster response to crises.

In preparation for the summit, the US has been pressing to include a reference in the resolution for more equitable distribution of the financing for peacekeeping. Washington would like to reduce its 25% share of this budget, council diplomats say.

The US was also unhappy at suggestions that the council should pledge to consider time limits when imposing sanctions. Under criticism for its sanctions on Iraq, the council had begun giving time limits for sanctions, but the US has resisted making this a policy.

Reflecting fears that the voices of the developing world and the non-governmental organisations will fall on deaf ears, an alternative summit has been scheduled to take place at the same time. The key speaker at this "State of the World Forum" will be the former Russian president, Mikhail Gorbachev.

A spokesman for the alternative summit said it will provide a platform for the kind of dissenting voices heard only on the streets at recent international meetings.

webTitle: Budget may force RAF to scrap planes, says report

fields.headline: Budget may force RAF to scrap planes, says report
fields.trailText: Severe pressure on the defence budget has forced the RAF to consider deep cuts in its expenditure, including scrapping one of its frontline aircraft, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Severe pressure on the defence budget has forced the RAF to consider deep cuts in its expenditure, including scrapping one of its frontline aircraft, it emerged yesterday.

A leaked classified document concludes that the RAF has no alternative to what it calls a "radical fleet option" - abandoning or reducing the number of F3 Tornadoes, the RAF's main air defence fighter, the Jaguar fighter-bomber, or the Royal Navy's Sea Harrier.

The document recommended £1.5bn cuts in RAF spending over the next 10 years. Such is the scale of budgetary pressures facing the Ministry of Defence that it is contemplating cutting the number of Eurofighters ordered by the RAF - a move that would be hugely embarrassing politically.

It also considered the possibility of abandoning plans to build two new aircraft carriers.

The document, marked "Confidential - UK eyes only", was written by a senior RAF officer for the attention of Vice Admiral Jeremy Blackham, a deputy chief of defence staff. It was leaked to the BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

Lewis Moonie, the junior defence minister, insisted yesterday that the document, dated July 14, was "purely speculative" and drafted from a set of assumptions which had now been discarded.

He suggested that a 0.1 % real increase in the £23bn defence budget, announced on July 17, made the document irrelevant. However, it is known that the proposals were discussed by a standing committee of RAF officers on August 2, after the budget increase was announced.

The RAF's performance in the Kosovo war revealed a shortage of "smart" bombs, inadequate comunications and a shortage of aircraft spares. The leaked document considered alternative options of "salami chunking" - slicing a bit off all programmes - or rethinking "big commitments".

These commitments include the plan to build two aircraft carriers due to enter service in 2012 and 2015 at a combined cost of £2bn, and the multinational Eurofighter project.

Along with the Trident nuclear missile system, the Eurofighter was protected from scrutiny by the 1998 strategic defence review. Ministers have gone along with the previous Tory government's decision to buy 232 Eurofighters at an estimated cost of £15bn.

The aircraft, conceived in the 1980s, was designed to combat Soviet warplanes during the cold war. Its manufacturers want to build a version capable of landing and taking off from aircraft carriers. However, the navy prefers the potentially cheaper option of buying a US joint strike aircraft now being developed.

The document said financial penalties for reducing the order for Eurofighters would mean that a cut would bring no savings.

Menzies Campbell, the Liberal Democrats' defence spokesman, said yesterday the report would send a "shiver of dismay" through the armed forces.

"This seems to be a return to the haphazard management of the defence budget which characterised the last 10 years of the previous government," he said.

"The amount of increase in the defence budget... is really very modest - by no means equivalent to the £1.5bn," he added.

He described the government's response to the leak as "unconvincing and disingenuous".

Mr Campbell added: "The strategic defence review was designed to bring an end to the mismatch between the budget and commitments, but this report suggests that there may be still a substantial gap."

The Conservative defence spokesman, Quentin Davies, accused the government of gambling with Britain's defence capabilities.

Defence "has not been given enough money. Our forces are overstretched," he said.

webTitle: Would you walk over hot coals for your boss?

fields.headline: Would you walk over hot coals for your boss?
fields.trailText: You can choose your friends but you can't choose your family. And as for your colleagues, well, you're stuck with them for eight hours a day whether you like it or not. But let's face it, going to work is about doing a task and getting paid for it - so does it really matter whether you get on with your workmates or not? Yes, according to most employers, which is why, sooner or later, your boss will be packing you off on a team building course.
fields.body:
You can choose your friends but you can't choose your family. And as for your colleagues, well, you're stuck with them for eight hours a day whether you like it or not. But let's face it, going to work is about doing a task and getting paid for it - so does it really matter whether you get on with your workmates or not? Yes, according to most employers, which is why, sooner or later, your boss will be packing you off on a team building course.

Team building has become very fashionable in recent years. It usually involves spending a day or two out of the office in a different part of the country. While there, you and your colleagues will take part in group activities which will supposedly encourage you to bond and be more productive back in the office. Assault courses were popular for a time but these days, you're more likely to find yourself skydiving, walking over hot coals or taking part in an acting workshop.

Only trouble is, it doesn't necessarily work, says Cary Cooper, professor of organisational psychology and health at the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology. "It's a good way of getting people away from the pressures of work. But just because you send your employees off to crew a yacht together for a week, it doesn't mean they'll get on," he points out.

"In fact, it could have the opposite effect. These activities only encourage team building if people are able to discuss their experiences afterwards and look at why they behaved the way they did. Unfortunately, very few employers do this."

Engineer Anne Whittaker, who works for a telecommunications firm, agrees. "I've been on so many of these things now that I'm getting fed up with them," she says. "I sometimes wonder whether it's a cop-out for the company. It's all very well sending people off on courses in the hope that they'll come back to the office and sort out their problems, but if they don't ask for feedback, what's the point?"

Nevertheless, Whittaker feels she has learned from her experiences. "I don't know whether it's made much difference to how we all get on in my department because we all lead quite separate lives," she says. "But it's good to see your workmates in different roles. The bosses get to see that the secretaries are capable of other things, too. On one course, we had to get into teams and build a mobile," she continues. "One of my team-mates ran out of the room crying. It turned out she couldn't handle the way this bloke and I were speaking to each other. She thought we were too forceful. I was quite shocked because I thought we were just having a discussion but it made me more aware of the effect you can have on other people without realising it."

Wacky activities are about more than just improving staff relations, says Professor Cooper. "Some companies want to be 'with it' so they send employees on the most exotic courses they can think of," he comments. "It's a form of corporate competition. It's also a way of rewarding staff without paying tax."

Joanna Skilton is a PA with a large financial firm in the City. She thoroughly enjoyed the day she and 300 colleagues spent at a samba drumming workshop. "We were each given an instrument to play and taught to play samba rhythms in small groups," she says. "At the end, all 300 of us played together, which was great. It made me feel more confident because I could see how we achieved a lot together in a short space of time. We were still taking about it months later."

So next time you find yourself dancing naked round a camp-fire or learning the trombone in the name of team building, take the opportunity to get to know what your colleagues are really like, Professor Cooper advises. Otherwise, just enjoy it. After all, the company's paying.

fields.headline: How to... avoid working weekends
fields.standfirst: Long hours will take their toll on your health
fields.trailText: Long hours will take their toll on your health
fields.body:
When Jonathan Maynard, an IT programmer, realised that he was going to have to work the Bank Holiday weekend, it was the last straw. "I've had enough," he admits, and he has decided to look for a new job.

"There is a real culture of working weekends in my office - if you don't put in extra hours, you're seen as not pulling your weight. It all comes down to my boss. He's divorced and lives for his job - he's in every weekend. He expects the same of his staff, and if you try to mention that you do have a life outside the office, he makes it clear that he disapproves," he says.

Maynard's experience may seem a little extreme, but the fact is that working weekends is becoming increasingly common. "The buzz word over the last few years has been 'downsizing'," says Dr Stuart Metcalfe, senior lecturer in management at South Bank University. "This generally means utilising less staff - and anyone who wants to keep their job ends up having to take on more responsibilities. Employers are putting more and more strain on people and there is considerable pressure to work longer hours."

Of course, there is always the option to simply refuse to spend your weekend cooped up in the office, but it can be hard if everyone else appears happy to come in. "I've always thought you should work to live, not the other way round," says Maynard, "and although some of my colleagues agree with me, none of them will actually stand up to my boss and refuse to work weekends.

"The stupid thing is, very little work actually gets done on the weekend - the important thing is to be seen turning up."

According to Imogen Daniels, adviser at the Chartered Institute for Personnel and Development (CIPD), achieving a balance between life and work is something that is currently preoccupying both the CIPD and the government. "There's a lot of talk about work/life balance at the moment," she says. "and one of the central problems is the different perception of work between generations.

"People in their 20s view work very differently to people in their 40s. They don't expect a job for life, they are much more flexible. But in return they don't expect to have to work seven days a week. Older bosses may be less relaxed about their job - and think nothing of working a Saturday or Sunday."

The important thing to remember is that however much pressure there seems to be, it is unlikely that you are contractually obliged to turn up on weekends. "It's important when you take a job to understand all the contractual implications," believes Daniels.

"And not just those written down. Every workplace also has an unspoken cultural contract - which includes whether working long hours is accepted." But work is a two-way street - it's also imperative to make clear what you will not accept, including working weekends, right from the start.

But pressure from colleagues and the boss is not the only reason for working weekends. "I simply had too much work to get through in the week," says Caroline Adams-Hart, who works as a design editor on a glossy magazine. "My deputy left and in a cost-cutting exercise the powers-that-be decided not to replace her. We were all supposed to absorb her workload - but we were frantically busy already. After only a couple of weeks I was starting to work every weekend - just to keep my head above water."

The irony with this sort of situation is that working longer hours rarely means increased productivity. "No one can work seven days a week and produce their best work," believes Dr Metcalfe, "and the best thing to do in this situation is admit that you're drowning under work.

"Most bosses will respect an employee being honest about their workload - but unless they are told they can't do anything to improve the situation. You have to be proactive and make your situation clear - before the deterioration in your work, and probably appearance, makes it obvious anyway."

Adams-Hart agrees. "I worked every weekend for six weeks and I was exhausted," she admits. webTitle: Are you a model candidate: a 2:1 who's fun?

fields.headline: Are you a model candidate: a 2:1 who's fun?
fields.standfirst: Graduates can benefit from employer branding as recruitment practices are revolutionised
fields.trailText: Graduates can benefit from employer branding as recruitment practices are revolutionised
fields.body:
How can you find out what it is really like to work for an organisation? The biggest difficulty for applicants has always been obtaining quality information. Those looking for a job would love to know if the training scheme is all it is cracked up to be, or if the promise of early responsibility is anything more than words. Unfortunately, it is just this type of information which is the most difficult to access. There are however indications that this is beginning to change.

Traditionally, graduates have had to rely on limited resources. These include:

The company brochure - which is as objective as any sales pitch.

A trusted confidante - who works for the organisation and is usually a friend of the family. His or her opinion is often given considerable credence but it is easily forgotten that this is only one point of view.

Peer endorsement - which involves the most presentable graduate trainees talking up their employer at campus events (personal endorsement being one of the oldest techniques in advertising).

Hearsay - which becomes a resource because information is so scarce.

The paucity of these resources is now being improved however. This year, BT is introducing a facility giving applicants access to the email addresses of graduate trainees within the company. Applicants can then ask anything about the organisation they wish, both parties being safe in the knowledge that their communication is effectively uncontrollable.

Such thinking represents a watershed in graduate recruitment. By providing graduates with the opportunity to ask pertinent and impertinent questions outside the ambit of those who will be making the hiring decisions, the company is demonstrating two things.

First, it is showing respect for the things the applicant might want to know but which are difficult to ask at interview.

Secondly, it is demonstrating its trust in the professionalism of its employees. Both of these aspects emerge from the deliberate introduction of employer branding.

According to Simon Barrow of People in Business which developed the concept, the employer brand "is about applying to the employment experience the same care and coherence used by good marketing and sales people in the management of valued customers. It is not exclusively concerned with recruitment, but is a strategy for managing all aspects of the employee relationship."

Just as sales strategies have evolved towards a greater emphasis on retention, and purchasing relationships have become more like partnerships, so the other major business activity, employment, is moving towards a more equitable footing.

In the traditional mindset, the graduate sent the company whatever information it demanded while the company held back as much as it could. Forward-looking companies now aim to give their applicants as much information as they can.

"Too many companies see graduate recruiting as essentially a sales job," says Emma Howell, graduate manager at Tesco, a company noted for its work on employment branding.

"Instead it should be about providing applicants with the information they need to make an informed choice. We take applicants to a store and let them talk to the manager and a graduate trainee for an afternoon, well away from anyone involved in the decision-making process.

"This is about providing proper access to information, not controlled access."

A few hours may not seem a lot, but as everyone in human resources knows, one cynical manager can destroy a carefully crafted corporate image in less than a minute.

This new attitude to recruitment and retention is still not widespread. In a poll conducted by People in Business amongst delegates at the Association of Graduate Recruiters' annual conference, most employers who responded said that they had only heard of the concept of employer branding in the last year or so, while only three companies claimed that they were already recognised for their employer brand management.

Despite this general lack of activity, the most forward-thinking companies are pushing the development because they realise that it will have an impact on their bottom line.

"Every company wants to employ the 2.1 who's fun," says Simon Barrow. "That is, a graduate with a mix of intellectual and social skills who can thrive in the technologically sophisticated and sales-orientated environment that exists in business today. These people are scarce, and if companies cannot recruit and retain them they will fail to compete.

"Employer branding gives companies a coherent management strategy for keeping the talent within the organisation."

In the long term, whether a company chooses to pursue employer branding will affect far more than the applicant's ability to make informed choices.

Its use will determine whether graduates are joining a successful, forward-thinking organisation and, because employer branding is also concerned with issues such as mana-ging the work/ home balance, in the long term this could affect the quality of their lives.

fields.headline: Keegan shuns the busted flush
fields.standfirst: Kev plays a canny hand when he might have stuck, but is he just bluffing?
fields.trailText: Kev plays a canny hand when he might have stuck, but is he just bluffing?
fields.body:
For a losing England coach who is adamant he will not fall on his sword, Kevin Keegan appears to be cutting it rather fine in his choice of team for tonight's match against France.

Needing to restore credibility to the national side and his handling of it following the failures of Euro 2000, as well as laying the foundations for the 2002 World Cup qualifiers, Keegan's team to face the world and European champions in the Stade de France is daring or daft depending on one's point of view.

More probably it is a bit of both. In some respects Keegan, overtaken by caution in the European Championship, has rediscovered his old bravura. Now that Alan Shearer has retired from international football, Keegan has abandoned the idea of playing with two out-and-out strikers. Andy Cole will lead the attack with Paul Scholes, a Manchester United team-mate, playing off him rather than alongside him.

In addition David Beckham will operate in a central role with Darren Anderton returning on the right wing. Shearer required automatic service from the flanks but since he is no longer an option Keegan and his attackers should enjoy greater freedom as they seek a combination to penetrate the defences of Germany and Finland in the World Cup just over a month from now.

For the moment Michael Owen has lost his place as a first-choice striker although the Liverpool player may well reappear at some point tonight. Keegan clearly wants to see if the rounding out of Cole's game at Old Trafford can be reproduced at international level. Another flop, however, and Cole's best chance of an England career will surely have disappeared forever.

Clearly Beckham's revised role is the key. "This is a great opportunity for David Beckham to show that he can run the game from that position," Keegan explained. "I know it's a role he can play. Sometimes he has tended to be a bit isolated on the right wing."

With Anderton and Nick Barmby giving them natural width England should not be short of the means to disturb a French back four which has yet to play on a losing side and will be keen to keep this record intact as Laurent Blanc, like Didier Deschamps, plays in his last international. The Manchester United goalkeeper Fabien Barthez, however, will not play owing to an ankle injury.

England's own defence will be a back four without full-backs thinly protected by a non-tackling midfield. Had he been fit, the 20-year-old Steven Gerrard would have been the anchor man. Instead it will be the 33-year-old Dennis Wise, an occasional nicker of the ball for Chelsea but out of his depth in this sort of company.

Wise is there, rather than Paul Ince, because Keegan feels he needs someone who can play the ball accurately from deep positions, as Wise certainly did during the scoreless friendly against Argentina at Wembley in February.

Keegan is conscious of the need for England to play the ball more constructively from the back than they did in Euro 2000, when they tended to whack it upfield vaguely in Shearer's direction, a habit which ensured it returned at even greater speed. This is why the 19-year-old Gareth Barry has been chosen on the left side of defence. "He's a good user of the ball who doesn't get flustered," said Keegan, "and you do tend to get a little more time at international level."

That said, Barry is one of a back three at Villa Park with limited experience of full-back play. Similarly Sol Campbell will play at right-back purely on the evidence of a competent game in that position when England won the opening leg of their European Championship play-off against Scotland at Hampden Park.

True, Campbell readjusted his game on that occasion but if Thierry Henry takes him on as he did a tiring Fabio Cannavaro when France beat Italy in the Euro 2000 final the Tottenham defender's limitations as a right-back will surely be exposed.

Phil Neville, whose foul on Viorel Moldovan in the last minute gave Romania the penalty from which they sent England packing from Euro 2000, is a more natural right-back and may yet come off the bench tonight, if only to preserve his distinction of being the only player to appear in every one of Keegan's teams.

Maybe Keegan is being cute. Few expect England to beat France tonight and many will be pleasantly surprised if they avoid defeat. So why not gamble a little and try something different? Better that, Keegan might argue, than try to revive a busted flush through a cursory shuffle of the pack.

He has been in the job for just over a year of a three-year, £3m contract. Fourteen months ago the Football Association and the nation begged him to take over the moribund squad left by the sudden departure of Glenn Hoddle.

Now the punters are placing bets on when Keegan will go and the identity of his successor, while a bad result and performance tonight will hasten the moment when at least one member of the FA international committee publicly expresses his doubts about the way England are being run.

That the international committee rarely agrees on anything unanimously except lunch would be of scant consolation for Keegan, who has never pretended to be a miracle worker but was expected to work them all the same. Should England win tonight even the agnostics may be converted.

webTitle: Wily Brown confronts an English enemy and a Baltic banana skin

fields.headline: Wily Brown confronts an English enemy and a Baltic banana skin
fields.standfirst: Group Six: Latvia v Scotland
fields.trailText: Latvia are on a good run of form, possess a clutch of Premiership players and their manager's an Englishman. Thomas Kerr checks the Tartan Army's nerves in Riga.
fields.body:
For many Scots the thought of another World Cup campaign is almost too much to bear. The road is strewn with potential embarrassments and headline humiliations when so-called lesser nations form the opposition, as in this group. It is as well Scotland long ago gave up any notions of being among the tyrants of international football.

Tonight in Latvia, some of the 2,000-strong Tartan Army will be fortified with drink and have their hands over their eyes in case this opening qualifier turns into one of Scotland's patented disasters.

Worryingly, Latvia have claimed a few hides recently, those of Norway (3-1 away), Greece and Finland. They also currently have several players carving out decent careers in Britain. These facts alone induce quiet terror.

Some Scotland players - Allan Johnston, Colin Hendry and Christian Dailly - are not even getting club games. Two other key men, Paul Lambert and Craig Burley, are injured. It is at times like these that Craig Brown's ability to pluck cockney sparrows such as Neil Sullivan and Matt Elliott from the trees inspires gratitude.

The mere mention of Brown, of course, dispels some gloom. This little general is about to direct his 62nd international and is battle-scarred from the business of grabbing results. Brown's Scotland have been to England, Ireland, Germany and Holland recently and come back with three wins and a draw. This might not be miraculous, but for the Scots it is certainly tremendous.

"I'm trying to change our style to make us a bit more attack-minded," Brown said yesterday, a reference to his abandoning his warlike 3-5-2 formation to something resembling a 3-4-3 with pacy wingers. "In the past we haven't had the players to try out this shape but I'm keen to use Neil McCann and Allan Johnston to see if it works."

Brown tonight will be up against the Englishman Gary Johnson, whose bizarre career has taken him from playing in Sweden to coaching Cambridge United and Newmarket Town before a phone call last year lured him to a London hotel. Within 30 minutes, he had become Latvia's new manager.

Johnson startled Brown yesterday by asking if he could attend a Scotland training session. The affable Brown found that odd but agreed to it. "I just made sure our players didn't then go through our throw-in, free-kick and corner routines," he said.

With opponents like Marian Pahars, the eager Southampton striker, and Andrejs Stolcers, a forward currently bursting with goals for Spartak Moscow, Scotland will also require Brown to be at his wiliest tonight

Scotland: Sullivan (Tottenham); Boyd (Celtic), Hendry (Coventry), Dailly (Blackburn); McNamara (Celtic), Ferguson (Rangers), Cameron (Hearts), Davidson (Blackburn); Hutchison (Sunderland) or Johnston (Rangers), Dodds, McCann (both Rangers)

fields.headline: Rangers news breaks Record
fields.standfirst: With the World Cup qualifiers upon us, most of Scotland is still hung over from last week's Auld Firm game
fields.trailText: With the World Cup qualifiers upon us, most of Scotland is still hung over from last week's Auld Firm game.
fields.body:
Glasgow was the place to be this week, in the fallout to the game the green half of the city has already concluded was the greatest Old Firm derby of them all. The streets were packed with green-hoop-clad individuals beaming. And that was a full five days after the 6-2 drubbing of Rangers.

Naturally enough, the papers also could not get enough of the story. The build-up to Scotland's tricky away tie with Latvia was entirely dominated by what would happen when Rangers' Barry Ferguson and Celtic's Jonathan Gould met up in the national squad after their fisticuffs on Sunday. Nothing, it seems, gets in the way of the Old Firm soap opera, not even the start of another World Cup qualification campaign.

Indeed, many a conspiracy theorist was speculating that Rangers' purchase of Ronald de Boer and attempt to sign John Hartson were entirely motivated by a need to seize the public relations initiative. Never mind that Ibrox's already bloated squad had no need of fresh recruits, it was vital the back page of the Record was no longer hijacked by gloating Celts.

If that was the intention, it didn't quite work. As it happens the Record - the Rangers fan's journal of choice - contrived not to notice the imminent arrival of Frank de Boer's less talented twin until after its rivals. It was a miss of such gravity, it set in train a series of events that culminated in the sacking of the paper's editor, Martin Clarke.

Good to know they don't take their football too seriously north of the border.

As it happens the Record - the Rangers fan's journal of choice - contrived not to notice the imminent arrival of Frank de Boer's less talented twin until after its rivals. It was a miss of such gravity, it set in train a series of events that culminated in the sacking of the paper's editor, Martin Clarke. Good to know they don't take their football too seriously north of the border.

fields.headline: Doing it by the book
fields.standfirst: The 'Posh and Becks' palaver and the riddle of those missing 200 words
fields.trailText: The 'Posh and Becks' palaver and the riddle of those missing 200 words
fields.body:
There is only one question on the mind of the inquisitive this week: what is contained in those missing 200 words? What joys, gems and secrets did David and Victoria Beckham resort to the law to have removed from Andrew Morton's unauthorised biography?

The couple went to court seeking an injunction to stop publication of about half of the 60,000 words of Morton's imaginatively titled "Posh and Becks". But after advice from their QC Michael Tugendhat - whose fees make Roy Keane's remuneration look like loose change - the pair settled for only 200 being edited out of the final version. Two hundred words that immediately became real currency.

"We are not allowed to discuss what has been taken out," says Michael O'Mara, the publisher of the tome that has so offended England's finest footballer and his wife. "The only thing I can say is what has been removed I don't give a damn about."

Which leaves the rest of us speculating. Was it the bit about David giving Victoria singing lessons? Was it the suggestion that Victoria finds all that training business her husband goes in for an unnecessary distraction from the serious world of shopping and film premieres? Or was it the revelation that Brooklyn had signed pre-school forms with Manchester City?

In the meantime, in court there was much talk of moral high ground; the Beckhams wanting to protect their privacy, Morton citing lofty principles of freedom of speech. Actually, this is not a debate about ethics. It is significantly more straightforward.

Morton is no whistle-blowing champion standing on the barricades to defend the inalienable right of all of us to say what we wish in print. He wants to make money from tittle-tattle about a saleable couple. And if the Beckhams were so anxious that their life remain totally private, it is unfortunate that in the very week of the case, David had invited OK! into his home for an 18-page photo shoot. He is, in case you missed it, a dab hand with the pasta.

No, what the case was about was control. Control of image, control of distribution and, most importantly, control of income. Since the football boom, as players have gradually realised there is a fortune in their face as well as their feet (though probably not in David Hopkin's case), a paranoia has developed within the game that vast sums of money are being made by outsiders which should rightly belong in the participants' pockets.

As journalists engaged in trying to report on the business are increasingly discovering, faxed requests for media interviews these days often come back with the scribbled message: "What's the fee?" And when the putative interviewee is informed that some newspapers don't pay, the standard football-speak response has become: you're hoping to sell papers off me, why shouldn't I get a slice of the action?

If the argument seems ferociously mercenary, it is understandable how it arises. This week, after Luis Figo relinquished all his commercial rights to his new employers, the president of Real Madrid, Florentino Perez, claimed that his club would be able to recoup all £37m of the transfer fee for the player by exploiting his image.

"Figo is the first player to cede his image rights to the club," Senor Perez said on announcing the Real deal. "Selling those rights worldwide will be worth a lot of money. I hope Figo will turn out to be free by the end of the six years of his contract."

Such optimism suggests that either Senor Perez has tapped into a huge reservoir of money in sales of posters, lunchboxes and computer mousemats bearing the face of a popular footballer, or that he is hopelessly naive. But if Perez is right, then David Beckham and his busy wife would be crazy not to make every effort - even going to law - to retain control over the trade in their celebrity. It is not greed, it is common sense. Particularly when it was revealed in court that Beckham's own authorised book - My World - is to be published in the very same week as Morton's effort.

All this, however, casts an entertaining spin on Michael O'Mara's other post-court case comment about those excised 200 words.

"The Beckhams," he says, "objected to material describing the way they attempt to control their media image, rather than intimate personal details."

If O'Mara is right about the disputed content, then evidently the Beckhams were prepared to go far as the High Court to prevent the revelation that they like to exercise control over their media image. It is an irony presumably lost on the couple and their pricy advisers. But it is one the rest of us can enjoy hugely.

fields.headline: Blair answers Booth on pensions
fields.trailText: When he walked through the door of 10 Downing Street for the first time, Tony Blair must have known the ability to handle criticism was necessary to his new job.
fields.body:
When he walked through the door of 10 Downing Street for the first time, Tony Blair must have known the ability to handle criticism was necessary to his new job.

But while he was no doubt prepared for censure from the opposition benches, he probably did not expect a regular slating from a good deal closer to home, his father-in-law.

In the latest episode of the prime ministerial family washing their its dirty laundry in public, Mr Blair was again yesterday forced to slap down criticism of his government from Tony Booth. Like rather a lot of British pensioners, Mr Boothis none too happy with the government's refusal to restore the link between earnings and the state pension.

He doesn't, however, blame his son-in-law directly for the last government-approved increase, which saw a single person's payment rise by just 75p rise in a single person's pension.

Mr Booth blames chancellor Gordon Brown and wants Mr Blair to loosen the iron chancellor's purse strings.

"The prime minister is the first secretary of the Treasury," said Mr Booth. (Mr Blair is first lord)."He has the authority to intervene and correct the mistakes and miscalculations of this chancellor and he should do so."

So incensed is Mr Booth at what he sees as the government's miserliness, that he is lending his support to the National Pensioners' Convention, a group which campaigns for the restoration of the earnings link so poorer pensioners do not have to rely on means-tested benefit.

In pursuit of the campaign, Mr Booth yesterday appeared on Radio 4's Today programme.

He said: "The government can afford it because we know that the national insurance fund has a surplus of over £5bn and by 2002 this will be doubled to almost £10.5bn."

The prime minister, in Scotland chairing a meeting of the joint ministerial committee before spending a weekend with the royal family at Balmoral, was philosophical. Mr Blair said on Radio Scotland: "I don't think it will be the first time I had a little bit of grief from Tony along the way.

"If we were to re-link pensions to earnings, broken by the last government, the cost for future generations would be enormous.

"We have to look for more sophisticated and better targeted ways of helping [pensioners]."

If Mr Blair was not exactly receiving succour from his family yesterday, it did not stop him from offering also offered support to Scotland's beleaguered education minister, Sam Galbraith, who is under increasing pressure to resign over the exam results chaos. Mr Blair does not want him to go.

"In my view it would be very wrong if that happened," he said.

fields.headline: 22 banned under new hooligan law
fields.standfirst: Special report: football violence
fields.trailText: At least 22 known or suspected football hooligans have been prevented from attending the France v England match in Paris tonight under tough new legislation designed to stop troublemakers travelling abroad.
fields.body:
At least 22 known or suspected football hooligans have been prevented from attending the France v England match in Paris tonight under tough new legislation designed to stop troublemakers travelling abroad.

The National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS), which monitors football hooliganism, said last night that the number prevented from attending the match is likely to increase as police forces around the country step up security at rail and ferry terminals to prevent troublemakers leaving the country.

The Football Disorder Act, which came into effect on Monday, gives police the right to prevent even those who have not committed any offence from leaving the country or attending a match if it is felt they may cause trouble at some point. Hooligans can be banned for up to 10 years with orders applying to domestic and international matches.

Three banning orders were served earlier this week while another 19 supporters have been served with summonses ordering them to appear before a magistrate for a banning order hearing. They will not be allowed to leave the country until after their appearance.

Last Wednesday, Chris Sawford, 21, from Swindon, became the first person to be affected by the new legislation when he was served with a two-year banning order preventing him attending matches at home or abroad.

Yesterday Steven Turnball, 28, from Littlehampton, West Sussex, and his twin brother, Christopher, were also served with two-year orders.

Under previous legislation only those who had committed a football-related offence could be served with banning orders.

Police have the right to detain suspects for six hours before serving them with a notice to appear before a magistrate for a banning order hearing.

An NCIS spokeswoman said: "We expect the number of people prevented from attending the Paris match to increase. The new legislation is exactly what we wanted. For the first time it gives us the power to turn back troublemakers from our own border."

A security operation was launched at Manchester airport with police on the lookout for known or suspected hooligans. Insp Graham Lennie, of Greater Manchester police, said: "We are looking for people who are known to us, or who we can check for a history of violence, or who we believe will be at the match to cause trouble."

England fans have been given an allocation of 6,500 tickets for the match. Police do not expect any serious disorder at the friendly.

fields.headline: How French cut the mustard
fields.standfirst: After Italia 90, we got the Premiership and they got the best team in the world
fields.trailText: After Italia 90, we got the Premiership and they got the best team in the world.
fields.body:
As the French squad leave their quarters in the Chateau Montjoye at Clairefontaine this afternoon, en route to meet England on the other side of Paris, they will be watched by a group of boys who must know themselves to be the luckiest teenagers in world football. These are the new intake of students at France's Centre Nationale de Formation, the academy for elite footballers which has become the model for all such projects, thanks to the success of its graduates on the biggest of stages.

"The problem is that years ago young players used to play in the streets, the meadows and the open spaces," Gérard Houllier, one of the architects of the Clairefontaine project, told me when he was still the technical director of the French football federation. "Now, no more. When they see an open space, it's a car park. We've had to try and replace that, somehow." France's recent honours have been the measure of their success in translating the game of the streets to the manicured lawns of a country estate.

Tables have been turned, old assumptions reversed. Clairefontaine and the philosophy it represents are the reason why it is hardly an exaggeration to say that England will tiptoe into the silver saucer of the Stade de France for tonight's friendly match with the abashed air of impoverished peasants accepting a free meal from their aristocratic neighbours.

The analogy is not exact. Ironically, the disparity between tax laws on either side of the Channel means that the cash-rich Premier League has provided French fans with much of their best entertainment over the past month. Suddenly England is full of French footballers. The successful arrival of Fabien Barthez at Manchester United, the successive red cards earned by Patrick Vieira of Arsenal, the simmering row between Frank Leboeuf of Chelsea and his coach, Gianluca Vialli, the arrival of Sylvain Wiltord at Highbury and the brilliant contributions of Thierry Henry and Marcel Desailly to their respective London clubs have made headlines in the French sports pages.

Between their two historic triumphs in Paris and Rotterdam, France came to Wembley in February 1999 and, in the crumbling ancestral home that provides such a contrast with their own shining palace of modern sport, gave England a football lesson. Now French players are celebrated across the continent. After the draw for the Champions League group matches last week, L'Equipe proudly noted that, quite apart from those representing Paris St-Germain, Lyon and Monaco, no fewer than 20 French footballers would be involved in the competition, from Lionel Charbonnier at Rangers to Pascal Nouma at Besiktas, from Claude Makelele in Madrid to Bixente Lizarazu in Munich.

Ten years ago it was all very different. When France failed to qualify for the World Cup in Italy there was no great sense of surprise. The generation of Michel Platini, Jean Tigana and Alain Giresse - the central figures of the team that won the European Championship of 1984, and reached the semi-finals of the World Cups of 1982 and 1986 - had been a bit of a fluke, and everybody knew it.

When their successors failed again, four years later, it was rather more of a shock. Better things had been expected of the team of Jean-Pierre Papin, Eric Cantona and David Ginola, before the last-named misdirected a pass that enabled Bulgaria to snatch a last-minute victory at the Parc des Princes in the final qualifying game.

But by the time Ginola made the mistake that ended his international career the French football federation had already laid the foundations for a very different future. A far-reaching scheme for identifying and educating talented young players, created by the team of Houllier, Aimé Jacquet and Roger Lemerre, was in place, with results that we have seen over the past two years. France won the World Cup of 1998 on home soil under Jacquet, recaptured the European Championship in Holland this summer under Lemerre and will in all probability travel to the Far East in 2002 as favourites to continue their run of success. Now France is quite simply the worldwide example for the production of young footballers.

Such phenomena tend not to last for ever. Not so long ago the English FA was being regularly advised to follow the example of its German counterparts when it came to ensuring a rational succession from one national coach to another. Who, surveying the wreckage of Germany's campaigns in 1998 and 2000, would emulate them now? Yet it is hard to find evidence for the proposition that the French are likely to be resting on their laurels any day now. Behind the Zidanes, the Desaillys and the Thurams are another talented generation - among them the midfielders Peter Luccin of Paris St-Germain and Vikash Dhorasoo and Steed Malbranque of Lyon, the defender Philippe Christanval of Monaco, and the goalkeepers Sébastien Frey of Internazionale and Mickael Landreau of Nantes.

Yet even that generation could be out of luck. Laurent Blanc and Didier De schamps are saying adieu tonight, after winning more than a century of caps apiece, but most of the senior squad will want to stay around and defend their world title in two years' time, which could force some of their putative successors to miss a turn. And coming up behind is another bunch of outstandingly gifted performers, such as Philippe Mexes, Auxerre's composed 18-year-old libero, and Bernard Mendy, PSG's versatile 19-year-old attacker.

In the French system continuity is everything - not least continuity of care and supervision, exemplified by the practice of giving each intake of international players a coach of their own, one who stays with them for five years, all the way from the Under-15 to the Under-20 stage. The potential benefit is obvious.

And so is the contrast. While France were failing to qualify for Italia 90, and facing their Year Zero, England were reaching the semi-finals, where Bobby Robson's team went out on penalties to the eventual winners. With a line-up including Peter Shilton, Des Walker, Paul Gascoigne, Peter Beardsley and Gary Lineker, they considered themselves unlucky not to have made further progress, and saw no reason not to view the future with optimism. The catastrophe of their failure, under Graham Taylor, to reach USA 94 was eventually obscured by the weird euphoria of Euro 96, in which another semi-final defeat by Germany, this time under Terry Venables, was somehow made to feel like a victory manqué, but their performances in France 98 under Glenn Hoddle and at Euro 2000 under Kevin Keegan reasserted the unsettling pattern of expectation and disappointment.

Continuity, planning, vision, personal modesty and collective will - all these qualities, so vital to the ascent of the French - have been notable by their absence from England's progress over the last decade. Perhaps, thanks to Howard Wilkinson's friendship with Houllier, the lesson has been learnt, although it is hard to see how an entirely club-based academy system can produce the same results, given the natural selfishness of market-driven commercial enterprises. Tonight's visit to the Stade de France will provide a reminder that Zinedine Zidane's genius certainly wins big matches, but anyone who believes that individual talent alone represents the difference is playing the ball down the wrong channel.

webTitle: So the rich get richer and the rest get stuffed

fields.headline: So the rich get richer and the rest get stuffed
fields.standfirst: The abolition of transfer fees will see football bled dry by the celebrated few
fields.trailText: The abolition of transfer fees will see football bled dry by the celebrated few.
fields.body:
In football the tills are alive to the sound of a new music. The air is filled with rejoicing as the leading players - and their agents - consider the lucrative consequences of the imminent abolition of transfer fees.

The acceptance by Fifa that the buying and selling of human beings who can kick a ball better than most is contrary to the free movement of labour as laid down in the Treaty of Rome looks set to trigger off a gold rush compared to which the free-for-all which followed the Bosman ruling will seem like diving for pennies.

When Sepp Blatter, the president of Fifa, answered the European Commission's challenge to the principle of transfers by admitting that the system had to end he surely wound up a saga which has lasted the best part of 40 years. It began with George Eastham challenging the right of Newcastle United to keep him when he wanted to join Arsenal and eventually winning his case in the High Court, which ruled the old retain-and-transfer system illegal in law.

Yet freedom of contract was not accepted by the ante-diluvian Football League until 1978 and even when, five years ago, the European Court of Justice upheld the Bosman decision, which barred transfer fees for players out of contract, clubs continued to pay spiralling amounts to strengthen their squads.

The removal of the limit on the number of foreign players teams could field accelerated the process, culminating this summer in the £35m Lazio paid for an Argentine, Hernan Crespo, and the £37m that took Portugal's Luis Figo to Real Madrid.

Unchecked, it is clear that the game's plutocrats would quickly take the transfer record towards the £100m mark, with the clubs who are less well off benefiting from the inflationary feed-down. Now it would seem that this Gadarene rush to pursue a few outstanding footballers with ever-increasing amounts is about to stop.

The money will still flow but instead of flowing from club to club, with the financially anaemic relying on selling a player or two in order to stay alive, it will flood out of the game and into the pockets of those relatively few footballers whose talents are in the biggest demand.

Ever since the maximum wage was abolished in 1961 (a year which, incidentally, saw the first £100,000 transfer in Britain when Manchester City sold Denis Law to Torino) the game in England has been increasingly dominated as much by wealth as ability.

The prime motivation for the setting up of the Premier League was that fewer clubs would share a financial cake made considerably sweeter by BSkyB money. Next week some of the less well-endowed Premiership clubs will challenge the division of the latest TV windfall, a move bound to renew speculation about a breakaway into a European league by the wealthy few.

The prospect of ending the transfer system will further alarm the Premier League's lower-middle classes as much as it is already causing consternation in the Nationwide League. The idea that players' wages could be paid out of the gate receipts is as old hat as brown bowlers.

Any sadness Coventry City felt at losing Robbie Keane was softened by the £13m that Internazionale paid for him. Ipswich Town's successful promotion campaign last season was given added impetus by the £6.5m they received from Newcastle United for Kieron Dyer.

The notion that a satisfactory system of compensation can be devised for clubs losing players who, like Keane and Dyer, are between the ages of 18 and 24 is fanciful. Even if the EC agrees to Fifa's suggested compromise of abolishing transfers for players over 24, the game will still be stuck with the effects of inflated fees and wages. Most transfer fees are paid by instalments anyway.

For the players, doing away with fees will be a mixed blessing. Sure, they will have the basic right to change jobs and work for employers who pay the best wages. But, by the same token, employers will be able to dispense with their services more easily and, in a trade which at present accepts that injured workers can receive full pay for the time it takes them to recover, this could be a worry.

For certain players the transfer system has been an extra safeguard against peremptory dismissal. Footballers frequently in bother on or off the field might find they really do become more trouble than they are worth.

Unless the EC accepts Fifa's suggestion that players would be allowed to change clubs only once a year, and then only during a specified period, the anarchy always predicted when footballers get more freedom may become a reality.

As it is, with contracts lasting no more than a year and players over 24 having the right to end them at any time, the role of the manager might be reduced to pinning up team-sheets and talking to reporters. Managers, in fact, could be the new serfs in football - albeit serfs in Mercs.

webTitle: McIlroy on the offensive to combat home truths

fields.headline: McIlroy on the offensive to combat home truths
fields.standfirst: Group Three: N Ireland v Malta
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's manager still awaits his first victory at Windsor Park. Malcolm Brodie in Belfast.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland manager Sammy McIlroy and his squad are determined to kick-start their World Cup qualifying bid today with a decisive triumph over Malta and end a 22-month winless run at Windsor Park.

"That record simply isn't good enough. Indeed, it's embarrassing and our supporters deserve better," said McIlroy, who succeeded Lawrie McMenemy last January at the end of a Euro 2000 series which sent Northern Ireland's Fifa ranking plummet to 95th.

"We don't underestimate the Maltese," said McIlroy. "They will play tight at the back and make it difficult for us to break them down."

McIlroy will adopt an attacking policy aimed at providing service to David Healy, the Manchester United reserve striker who has scored four goals in four internationals.

N Ireland (probable): Carroll (Wigan); Nolan (Bradford), Murdock (Preston), Taggart (Leicester), Hughes (Newcastle); Johnson (Blackburn), Magilton (Ipswich), Lomas (West Ham, captain), Horlock (Manchester City), Elliott (Glentoran); Healy (Manchester United)

Malta (probable): Barry (Sliema); Chetcuti (Valletta), Debono (Valletta), Said (Floriana), Theuma (Valletta); Brincat (B'Kara), Camilleri (Sliema), Carabott (Hibernians), Turner (Sliema); Busuttil (Sliema) captain, Zahra (B'Kara) Referee: Taras Bezubiak (Russia)

webTitle: Wenger calls for strike over transfer plan

fields.headline: Wenger calls for strike over transfer plan
fields.standfirst: Arsène gets all insurrectionary after Fifa fails to consult the European game
fields.trailText: Arsène gets all insurrectionary after Fifa fails to consult the European game.Vivek Chaudhary on the game's looming crisis.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger last night called for strike action if proposals by Fifa which would abolish the transfer system and allow players over 24 complete freedom of movement are accepted.

The Arsenal manager was fiercely critical of Fifa's reaction to the European Commission's insistence that the existing system is unfair and must be scrapped.

Fifa's plans include abolishing transfer fees for players over 24 - allowing them to resign from their clubs at short notice - banning international transfers for players under 18 and compensating clubs for players between 18 and 24.

"We are all against that and I think there will be a huge strike if that goes through because nobody wants what Fifa is proposing," Wenger said. "They did nothing for two years; they didn't react at all.

"It is disrespect to the fans who love their players and their team. I feel really, really amazed that our football world would come up with that proposal."

Asked if he expected strike action in the event of the proposals going through, Wenger said: "I hope so."

Uefa joined the criticism of world football's governing body. Its chief executive Gerhard Aigner said Fifa's proposals were "not the result of an extended dialogue with professional football in Europe".

Aigner added: "Steps must be taken to safeguard the well-being of European football. We cannot allow change to happen without a full consideration of the consequences. The survival of European football is at stake and no one should reach a premature conclusion."

Fifa's attempt to try to solve the crisis surrounding the transfer system was further undermined when the commission said it was not satisfied with proposals to ban international transfers for players under 18.

Christophe Forax, the EC's spokesman, said they should have the right to live and work where they want within the 15 member states, like any other workers. "There are some principles on which we cannot yield," he said.

Leading European clubs have criticised the commission's intervention. Peter Kenyon, Manchester United's chief executive, urged the commission to reconsider."We all believe that for the betterment of football it will be better not to change," he said.

United's shares fell yesterday amid fears their leading stars could walk out on their contracts. Shares dropped by 3% to 292.5p before recovering to 295p late yesterday.

Fifa proposes a specific transfer period during which players will be able to move, with contracts lasting no longer than one year. Footballers will have the right to terminate a contract if they give a specific period of notice.

That could cause problems for many smaller clubs, who often rely on transfer income to balance the books.

The commission's attempt to try to treat football like any other business has again led to calls for a special protocol on sport, exempting it from European laws. France has been one of the leading voices in the campaign.

President Jacques Chirac said: "A working group at the level of European ministers has been created to consider how sports specifity within the European framework can be better taken into account. The sports movement knows that alone it will be powerless against those who wish to transform it into a purely commercial sector."

webTitle: Keane eager to justify star billing

fields.headline: Keane eager to justify star billing
fields.standfirst: Group Three: Holland v Rep of Ireland
fields.trailText: Inter's new recruit is upstaging Old Man Roy in the celebrity stakes in Amsterdam as Ireland prepare for their opener.Daniel Taylor in Amsterdam
fields.body:
Mid-afternoon outside the Amsterdam Hilton and a clutch of pre-pubescent star-spotters are hovering around Breitnerstraat, peering nervously through the majestic revolving doors and daring one another to cross the dividing line between their own world and the pampered domain of the professional footballer.

Inside, Robbie Keane is milling around the marbled foyer, signing autographs, posing for photographs. The Republic of Ireland squad have just arrived for tonight's World Cup qualifier against Holland and there is no doubt who is the star attraction. To his wide-eyed audience, the others are but a faceless blur. For all they could care, Roy Keane may as well be the bellboy.

After the World Cup, in the midst of Michael Owen hysteria, Niall Quinn told this newspaper there was a wiry young lad at Wolverhampton Wanderers who was better than Liverpool's own golden boy.

There were snorts of derision at the time, of course. But, in his quiet way, Keane Jr has lived up to the hype and more besides. Much more.

Now, little more than a month since swapping the Sky Blues of Coventry for the blue skies of northern Italy, Internazionale's new £13m forward is already a huge hit.

In Milan, replica jerseys emblazoned with his name are outselling those bearing the legend Ronaldo by almost two to one.

The fans love him and, for now at least, the notoriously fickle Italian media do, too. In his first competitive match, as a substitute for Ivan Zamorano in the Champions' League qualifier against Helsingborg, the 20-year-old announced his arrival by backheeling a shot against the post and then winning a penalty. It was missed and his team lost on aggregate.

"Why didn't Keane start?" shrieked Corriere dello Sport. "Of all Marcello Lippi's initial choices, none was as bad as the decision not to play Keane."

When Keane arrived in England, a bandy-legged 16-year-old, he was homesick and lonely but not once did he pursue a return to Dublin. It is his unbending demeanour that inspires hope he will prevail where so many others have buckled.

His work will be cut out. Inter's forward line is like a Who's Who of defenders' nightmares - from Ivan Zamarano to Christian Vieri, Hakan Sukur to Alvaro Recoba and, injury permitting, Ronaldo.

Yet Keane is far from overawed. "It should bring the best out of me," he says. "I would never have signed if I didn't think I had a chance of playing.

"You will have to ask me in a few months whether I'm a different player or a different person. But I won't be thinking that because I'm at Inter I'm automatically one of the best players in the world."

When Liam Brady went to Juventus he took an Italian/English dictionary everywhere he went. Keane reveals he, too, has a phrasebook almost permanently wedged in his back pocket.

"I'm doing all right, or at least that's what my teacher tells me she's very nice like that," he says.

"People who have been successful in Italy have all learned the language. I made a point of speaking to David Platt and he said it would help me to settle in so much quicker."

He is being helped by his new room-mate, Clarence Seedorf, who should also be on parade in the Amsterdam Arena this evening because of a rash of injuries that have ruled out almost an entire Dutch team.

"If there is such a thing as a good time to face Holland, this could be it," Keane volunteers. Yet, bravado aside, the Irish could not have asked for a much harder opening match.

It is a tough group with Portugal to come. If Keane's fame is to continue spreading, it may have to be with club rather than country.

Meanwhile, Keane's name-sake, Roy, will be the target of gamesmanship in Amsterdam, according to the Dutch defender Michael Reiziger. The comments, which he subsequently tried to play down, appeared on the Barcelona player's website.

"If we're smart we could get him a red card because he has a dodgy temperament," he said.

"We will have to provoke Keane in some way, perhaps holding his shirt or walking into him after he passes the ball.

"Players are also known to whisper comments about another player's mother or the size of his body parts. I don't like that side of the game very much but if it helps us to win then it's worthwhile."

webTitle: O'Neill gets his man as Thompson signs for Celtic

fields.headline: O'Neill gets his man as Thompson signs for Celtic
fields.trailText: Alan Thompson, once on the fringe of the England squad, was given a chance to resurrect his career yesterday when he signed for Celtic from Aston Villa for £2.75m.
fields.body:
Alan Thompson, once on the fringe of the England squad, was given a chance to resurrect his career yesterday when he signed for Celtic from Aston Villa for £2.75m.

Thompson, 26, moved to Villa from Bolton in 1998 despite O'Neill's best efforts to bring him to Filbert Street. "I tried to buy him at Leicester but he had the chance to go to a bigger club at Aston Villa and I've just followed his progress," O'Neill said.

The 26-year-old midfielder agreed a five-year contract after falling out of favour at Villa Park. Also arriving at Parkhead yesterday was the French striker Didier Agathe, who signed from Hibernian on a three-year deal at an estimated cost of £50,000.

The Manchester City manager Joe Royle has "relieved" Richard Edghill of the captaincy and dropped him for Tuesday's match at Leeds.

Edghill suffered a torrent of abuse from City's fans after scoring an own-goal in last Saturday's defeat by Coventry. "The decision is done for no other reason than to take the pressure away from Richard," Royle said. "I feel sorry for him. He loves this club but he hasn't had the best of starts."

Steve McManaman is in Real Madrid's 25-man squad for the Champions League. "The player received offers, some of them for more money than he's earning here, but he preferred to stay," said Real's coach Vicente del Bosque.

Rob Lee has signed a new one-year contract with Newcastle United.

Stockport took a 12th-minute lead last night but were beaten by two Tranmere goals in four minutes. Ian Moore struck before the home side countered through Wayne Allison and a Wayne Gill penalty.
