webTitle: Giggs shoulders burden as Wales seek instant replay

fields.headline: Giggs shoulders burden as Wales seek instant replay
fields.standfirst: Group Five: Belarus v Wales
fields.trailText: With the goal burden firmly on his shoulders, the Manchester United winger will be hoping for a repeat of his first visit to Minsk a year ago. Jon Brodkin reports from Belarus.
fields.body:
Ryan Giggs could do with history repeating itself when he steps out for Wales this afternoon.

When the Manchester United winger was last in Minsk, for a European Championship qualifier a year ago, he scored with four minutes remaining to clinch a 2-1 win.

That got Mark Hughes's tenure off to the ideal start and a similar opening to this World Cup campaign would be perfect. "It was one of my best moments for Wales," Giggs said.

The expectation heaped on Giggs is invariably huge when he plays for his country, and the 26-year-old has extra goalscoring responsibility today in the absence of Dean Saunders, who is injured, and John Hartson, who dropped out after his proposed move to Rangers fell through.

Not that Giggs sounds worried. "I accept what people have been saying, that I'm playing at my peak," he said. "Last season was a breath of fresh air for me. Before that I was always struggling with my hamstrings and struggling for fitness."

Hughes agrees that Giggs is "at the very height of his powers". He admitted yesterday the Wales job may have come a year earlier than he wanted but said he was not prepared to let the opportunity pass.

For him the serious business begins now with a squad also missing Mark Delaney, Matthew Jones and Kit Symons.

"I have noticed my personality has changed," Hughes said. "I used to be very mild-mannered and level-headed off the pitch but I get more worked up now. Maybe it's the baggage you have to carry around with you."

"I used to be very mild-mannered and level-headed off the pitch but I get more worked up now. Maybe it's the baggage you have to carry around with you."

webTitle: Omens bad as troubled Germans open campaign

fields.headline: Omens bad as troubled Germans open campaign
fields.standfirst: Germany can't afford to be superstitious as the World Cup qualifiers begin in earnest around Europe
fields.trailText: Germany can't afford to be superstitious as the World Cup qualifiers begin in earnest around Europe.
fields.body:
England's Group Nine rivals, Germany, go into their opening World Cup qualifier today beset by internal rows, superstition and the prospect of a stadium full of Greek fans.

After their dismal Euro 2000 performance, some confidence was restored by a 4-1 friendly win over Spain in new coach Rudi Völler's first match, but this week Völler came under fire from the perennial stirrer Franz Beckenbauer. The Bayern Munich president criticised Völler's decision to make Oliver Bierhoff captain as "a blatant mistake".

The match against Greece is Germany's first at Hamburg's Volkspark since 1988, when they lost 2-1 to Holland in the European Championship semi-final. The newly rebuilt 50,000-seat stadium was also the scene of West Germany's defeat by East Germany in the 1974 World Cup.

More alarming for the hosts is the thought that as many as half the crowd may be backing the visitors. The German FA fears a repeat of the final Euro 2000 qualifier against Turkey in October, when 40,000 Turkish fans turned Germany's qualification into an embarrassing anti-climax.

Newcastle's Nikos Dabizas has a knee injury, leaving Greece with a squad composed entirely of home-based players.

Völler is not the only new coach testing the waters as the European countries embark on the 229 remaining group matches, Estonia having kicked off with a 1-0 win over Andorra last month.

Giovanni Trappattoni takes his Italian squad to Hungary for tomorrow's match in Group Eight, while Senol Günes will be looking to consolidate Turkey's sprightly Euro 2000 performance with an opening win at home to Moldova.

Derby's Branko Strupar will be the centre of attention as he lines up for his adopted country, Belgium, against his native Croatia in the Group Six match in Brussels. "It will be a very emotional moment for me," he said. "I will feel as though I should be going into both changing rooms."

webTitle: Into the frying pan with dear Patrick

fields.headline: Into the frying pan with dear Patrick
fields.standfirst: Ron's in the dugout
fields.trailText: H oots! ... where's your trousers? ... isn't it? If you haven't guessed, I've been North of the Border for a look at the Scottish scene ... marvellous! ... Celtic Park! ... in Bonnie Scotland ... and a familiar face ... Martin O'Neill! ... bursting with boyish enthusiasm! ... Ho ho!
fields.body:
H oots! ... where's your trousers? ... isn't it? If you haven't guessed, I've been North of the Border for a look at the Scottish scene ... marvellous! ... Celtic Park! ... in Bonnie Scotland ... and a familiar face ... Martin O'Neill! ... bursting with boyish enthusiasm! ... Ho ho!

Infectious, isn't it? ... a meaningless fixture ... a woeful local tussle ... bit of a niggly skirmish ... but no animosity in the crowd! ... The Celtic supporters waving fondly to the departing Rangers fans ... five minutes before the whistle!

O'Neill? ... hmm? ... irrepressible ... isn't he! ... How would you repress him? ... Sit on him, Norm reckons ... We pinned him down after the game ... and offered our congratulations on his first "Auld Firm" match! Expectations up here might be hitting the roof ... but don't worry, he's not getting carried away!

"Fantasticdelightedunbelievableoutoftheblocksworldclassallofthemfantastic." Ho ho, irrepressible! ... And with that he wriggled free from our grasp, punched the air ... smacked his head off the roof ... and was carried away by a steward ... just a faint babbling in the distance ... "Worldclassfantasticimmense."

... Er ... how infectious is it?

Straight on the mobile after the game to old Ken Bates! ... difficult on the scooter ... involves a sort of chin-grip with a strange facial angle ... suggested the boy Sutton if he was looking for a striker! Which er ... led to a most enlightening exchange of views! ... er, which must remain off record I'm afraid!

And back home to a bumper postbag! ... A bulging sack! ... No football this week ... apart from a friendly kickabout with the French! ... They're a rugby lot really ... n'est ce pas? ... isn't it? So let's have some Readers' Letters!

Miss Katie Wedlake of South London writes: "In Italy you have to take a coaching course before becoming a manager. What about the FA sending Kevin on one of them - incognito, of course! Or do you think he wouldn't be so lovable if he wasn't a tactic-less twit?"

... Er ... yes ... Next!

Mr Mark Pitts of Chiswick asks: "Why are French players called things like 'Zizou' and 'Bobo' and that? Why don't they have manly nicknames like 'Chopper' or David 'Bites-yer-legs' Ginola?" ... Ho ho ... Good question! ... er ... Next!

Mr Mark Pitts of Chiswick asks: "What's all this sports nourishment about? ... what's wrong with good old-fashioned English grub?"

Well, Mark ... nothing! ... Remember Kevin's announcement on taking the England job? ... "Sausages are back on the menu!" ... He nearly got bowled over in the rush! ... Bit like that little misunderstanding over his "Plenty of talent in the dressing room!"

In my day it was fish and chips! ... washed down with a bottle of dandelion and burdock! ... Alf Tupper? ... hmm? ... marvellous! ... Kept the speed down! ... Allowed the creative players time to flourish ... none of that haring around!

It's all those dietary supplements to blame, isn't it? ... That Creatine stuff! Why do players today need performance enhancers? ... hmm? Why do they have to make Viagra so big? ... Whopping great blue pill ... damn difficult to swallow without a couple of tins of that isotonic drink I've been advertising recently on Sky! ... Great stuff!

Well, Patrick Vieira came in for a lot of stick last week ... seemed to be getting him down ... so the wife invited him round for dinner!

Ho ho! ... as part of Arsène Wenger's dietary revolution, you'd think he'd be a fussy eater ... but oh no! Good old fry-up ... chips, bangers, beans, bubble and a slice! ... and he was absolutely charm personified! ... Even helped with the washing up! Then I inadvertently got the handle of the chip-pan stuck up his shirt sleeve and ... Boof! ... out of the blue ... he elbowed me three times in the face ... Then on the Saturday he bangs in two goals! ... couldn't happen to a nicer fellow!

... Er, another Reader's Question! ... from Mr Mark Pitts of Chiswick! "I've got one of them Ruud Gullit wigs. What did he mean by sexy football? Was you a sexy footballer in your heyday?"

Well Mark, it's not just about poncing around in the wife's underwear is it? ... and oh yes! In my day I was ... I were a sexy footballer! ... Why do you young 'uns always think you invented it all? ... We'd regularly hit the fleshpots after a big game ... and sometimes before! ... Oh yes!

Ho ho! ... I remember me and Big Norm both dressed up as dollybirds, opening the door to a member of the constabulary and ... oh ... am I running out of space? ... Tonight's One To Watch!

Well, as Gérard Houllier ... who's French! ... says: "If anyone able of doing it ... Heskey able of doing it!" ... what? ...

Er ... tonight's One To Watch! ... self-effacing World Cup winner! ... Frank Leboeuf ... pronounced "Leboof" ... Restored to Chelsea's starting line-up ... Him and Vialli might not gel in the dressing-room ... but he's never been one to bury his head in the sand! ... Ostracised by his team-mates? ... ho ho ... Has Gazza ever been hippopotamised?

fields.headline: Slow-motion replay from wily Walsh
fields.trailText: When the ferocity of the West Indies pace attack was at its greatest, Andy Roberts, about as mean and snarling as a fast bowler could get, was asked whether he ever thought to employ a slower ball. His quicker one, he suggested, was the bouncer that struck the batsman on the helmet because he played too late. His slower one was the bouncer that struck him on the helmet because he played too early.
fields.body:
When the ferocity of the West Indies pace attack was at its greatest, Andy Roberts, about as mean and snarling as a fast bowler could get, was asked whether he ever thought to employ a slower ball. His quicker one, he suggested, was the bouncer that struck the batsman on the helmet because he played too late. His slower one was the bouncer that struck him on the helmet because he played too early.

Roberts was so fearsome that the main role of Richard Lewis, a Hampshire middle-order batsman, was to stand at short leg and help disoriented batsmen to their feet. For the likes of Roberts, Holding or Patterson to identify the need for a slower ball when the unremitting West Indies pace onslaught of the 70s and 80s was proving so destructive was simply unimaginable.

Graham Thorpe would be forgiven for wishing for a return to such straightforward times, when men were men and fast bowlers were the most manly of all. To fall to Courtney Walsh's slower ball once this summer was unnerving enough; to do so for a second time yesterday must make him question his faculties.

Walsh was once described by John Bracewell, briefly his coach at Gloucestershire, as more at peace with himself than any cricketer he had ever known. Tranquillity is the essence of his slower ball. It is so chilled out that occasionally it has been rumoured to utter the phrase "stay cool, man" as it drifts towards the batsman complete with dark glasses and Bob Marley songbook.

The Walsh dope ball has certainly made a dope out of Thorpe. His Test comeback at Old Trafford this summer lasted precisely one delivery as he lost the trajectory of a looping yorker that, at 64.7mph, was around 15-20mph short of Walsh's normal speed, turned away in alarm and was lbw. "It came out of nowhere," said Thorpe.

The speed gun measured Dope Ball II at 67mph, slightly faster, but to all intents and purposes the same delivery. This time Thorpe willed himself not to turn away, the warning "slower ball" messaged around his brain but the inswing struck his ankle as it defeated a fretful, groping push.

When it happened yesterday, he had been batting for one-and-a-half hours and, although he was never in touch, might have assumed he was seeing the ball pretty well.

Deceived batsmen often console themselves that the ball has passed over the top of the sightscreen, and since Chris Read was bowled for nought by Chris Cairns' slower ball at Lord's last summer, and his batting capabilities were outrageously ridiculed as a result, an additional white tarpaulin has been stretched across the boards at the Nursery End.

But English Test grounds could erect sightscreens as tall as the Ostankino television tower and Courtney's slower ball would still befuddle. The action remains as smooth and rhythmical as ever, the trap is silently sprung and the object is instant paralysis.

The finest West Indian exponent of the slower ball was arguably Franklyn Stephenson, who estimated in his Nottinghamshire "double" year of 1,000 first-class runs and 100 wickets that he had taken about one third of his wickets with slower ones. Brian Hardie was turned full circle by one that bowled him in a Benson and Hedges Cup final.

Not every bowler approaching the end of his career has been happy to win praise for his subtlety. Ted Dexter, the former England captain, whose brisk medium brought 66 Test wickets, described the day he realised that his zip had gone. "I took two catches off my own bowling against Glamorgan and was complimented on my cleverly disguised slower ball," he bemoaned.

More than one method is employed by the best practitioners. Some use the tips of the fingers, some prefer the palm ball, delivered from deep in the hand. Darren Gough, who has turned more balls this summer than Robert Croft, is now developing one that goes the other way. England, since Duncan Fletcher's arrival as coach, have been encouraged to add the weapon to their armoury.

The days of "running in faster and grunting" have long gone, and one-day cricket, often pilloried for wrecking techniques, can take some of the credit. Steve Waugh made wonderful use of the slow 'un in the 1987 World Cup, and Ian Harvey's perpetual changes of pace have made a massive contribution to Gloucestershire's run of four successive one-day trophies.

The master, though, is Courtney. Every ball is a little slower these days but the slowest ones of all have been one of the delights of the summer. Sleight of hand; great of stature.

fields.headline: West Indies weather the storm
fields.standfirst: Gough and Caddick make no headway but could still settle the issue today
fields.trailText: Gough and Caddick make no headway but could still settle the issue today. Mike Selvey at the Oval.
fields.body:
West Indies weathered the storm last night as England, sensing an opportunity to put the destiny of the series beyond doubt, threw the kitchen sink at them. Having bowled England out for 281 on a day sufficiently interrupted by rain that 42 overs were sacrificed, they were required to bat out 21 overs against Darren Gough and Andy Caddick with their dander up and a bellowing crowd egging them on.

Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith did not survive comfortably but survive they did in the 14 overs possible before another billowing dark cloud put paid to proceedings with seven overs remaining, reducing the deficit by 13.

It was a key session for West Indies in their quest for the victory against the odds that would thwart England at a time when they are brimmingly confident that they can at least secure the draw they need to win a series against this opposition for the first time in 31 years. Thus far West Indies have come back extremely well. From a situation shortly before tea on the first day when Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick had added 159 for the first wicket, they countered, taking all 10 wickets for 122 on a pitch that, while not entirely easy (it has too little substance to it for that) was never nasty.

Having been put in, England may have reasoned that 300 would be a competitive score, but after such a start they have most definitely underachieved. They could and should have put the game beyond West Indies in their innings and instead must bowl well today. If conditions remain as they are - dampish - and the pitch spends a clammy night under covers, batting will not be easy in the first hour today whatever the weather. Caddick and Gough still have it in their power to settle the issue first up.

They gave it a go last night in bright sunlight and with shadows stretched out along the turf. As Gough marked out his run from the Vauxhall end the crowd were already roaring their encouragement and Gough feeds off such support. At the other end Caddick surged in stiffly and ripped an awayswinger first ball past Campbell's bat. Both batsmen played and missed regularly, keeping the cordon of close catchers interested and the crowd gasping.

Twice, once against Caddick and then against Gough, Griffith could consider himself fortunate that he survived lbw appeals. The first, a brutish inswinger to which he offered no shot, appeared to have all the credentials and Caddick's appeal rent the air. A less benevolent umpire than David Shepherd might have sent the batsman packing. Later, in the final over before the light closed in, Gough produced another inswinger and it must have been the closest of calls as to whether it was just sneaking down the legside.

With considerable damage done to their efforts the previous evening there was much work to be done by the England batsmen when play resumed yesterday. With only the briefest interruption for rain inside the first 30 minutes, Thorpe and Hick batted for the best part of an hour-and-a-half in adding a further 34 runs, aided perhaps by Jimmy Adams' decision to withdraw Courtney Walsh from the attack after one over and replace him with Nixon McLean.

Hick had reached 17 when Curtly Ambrose constructed the over which dismissed him. First he sent a fielder back on the hook, and then followed with a brace of bouncers. Hick ignored them but they had served their purpose in pushing him back. When Ambrose then pitched well up, the batsman was stranded back in his crease and indisputably lbw. Ambrose, celebrating vigorously, appeared to enjoy the entrapment element as much as anything.

With one partner gone, after a sixth-wicket stand of 40, the other was to follow in spectacular fashion in the following over. By now Adams had recalled Walsh and, just as he had at Old Trafford for Thorpe's return to Test cricket, he produced a masterly slower ball - just 67mph compared to his normal 80-odd - that deceived the batsman once more into looking away. The ball struck him around the ankle and he too was lbw. In Manchester, Thorpe could console himself in the knowledge that it was his first ball. Here he had been batting for a total of 203 minutes for his 40, 85 minutes of them yesterday. Brilliant bowling can dismiss any batsman at any time.

Three overs but just one run later Dominic Cork became the third England batsman to fail to score. Ambrose now, having bowled 11 overs for only 13 runs, had been replaced at the Pavilion end by McLean and after a briefly frenetic liaison with Craig White, during which the Yorkshire all-rounder had all but been run out by Ridley Jacobs' direct hit, he heaved at a straight ball from McLean and was the third lbw victim of the morning and fifth of the innings.

Rain delayed the West Indies in their urgency to finish things off, but when they did get on White, Caddick and Gough all hit a boundary apiece before Caddick's feeble attempt to hook Walsh resulted in a gentle catch to short leg and Gough, batting like a No11, perished appropriately. Walsh, with three wickets, took his series total to 30. Heaven help batsmen when he gains some experience. f hand; great of stature.

Ambrose, celebrating vigorously, appeared to enjoy the entrapment element as much as anything. With one partner gone, after a sixth-wicket stand of 40, the other was to follow in spectacular fashion in the following over. By now Adams had recalled Walsh and, just as he had at Old Trafford for Thorpe's return to Test cricket, he produced a masterly slower ball - just 67mph compared to his normal 80-odd - that deceived the batsman once more into looking away. The ball struck him around the ankle and he too was lbw. In Manchester, Thorpe could console himself in the knowledge that it was his first ball. Here he had been batting for a total of 203 minutes for his 40, 85 minutes of them yesterday. Brilliant bowling can dismiss any batsman at any time. Three overs but just one run later Dominic Cork became the third England batsman to fail to score. Ambrose now, having bowled 11 overs for only 13 runs, had been replaced at the Pavilion end by McLean and after a briefly frenetic liaison with Craig White, during which the Yorkshire all-rounder had all but been run out by Ridley Jacobs' direct hit, he heaved at a straight ball from McLean and was the third lbw victim of the morning and fifth of the innings. Rain delayed the West Indies in their urgency to finish things off, but when they did get on White, Caddick and Gough all hit a boundary apiece before Caddick's feeble attempt to hook Walsh resulted in a gentle catch to short leg and Gough, batting like a No11, perished appropriately. Walsh, with three wickets, took his series total to 30. Heaven help batsmen when he gains some experience. f hand; great of stature.
